number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												A nice, casual point-and-click adventure game with resource management and a decent storyline, Hero of the Kingdom is a nice game that fulfills it's purpose, with low-to-no pressure on the player to get things done fast. It's easy to play, even while distracted. And thus definitely well-suited to a casual player, or someone who wants to play a little something that's not-too-engaging with a little free time. =Complete Review=  (TL:DR version and Conclusion at the bottom)=The Story: 3/5= You play as a farm boy with dreams of grandeur, of who's father has left you to take care of the farm while he takes care of some errands in town. One day, while you're out repairing the old lookout tower down the road from the farm, bandits set your father's farm ablaze. Not even raiding it, just raizing the whole thing! Now with no home, you must set out on a quest to find your father, who has not returned, and find out why the bandits destroyed your home. Throughout your adventure, you find many people in need of your aid. Some who also were hassled by the same bandits who burned your farm to the ground. And soon find that there are much bigger things at work than just the bandits. The story is engaging enough to encourage playing it through to the end, but simple enough to allow players to take a break if need be, with no pressure or timers.=The User Interface: 2/5=  The interface is barely there, which is nice for those who prefer a minimalistic UI. At each of the four corners of the screen, there are buttons to bring up the actual UI or to serve as a function of their own, of which they tuck themselves out of view when not moused over.  My only real complaint is how cluttered the inventory can get, but.. I figure one easy fix would be, I dunno... Cleaning it out?... I've got a problem with playing pack rat, yes...=The Gameplay: 3/5= The gameplay is pretty nice and simple. The layout is from a overhead view, and you click on what you want to interact with. Arrows at the edges of the screen indicate that you can move in that direction to another screen. Typically little icons will hover over things that need to be, or can be interacted with. But, as you progress through the game, there's more things to interact with that aren't highlighted. Hidden objects of a sort, if you will. Of which result in some very nice resources in-game, and achievements if you find a lot of them. =The Graphics: 3/5= The graphics are nice, sweet, and to the point. They're well done, and it's not often that there's sprites or the like that overly clash with the area. Everything blends well together, and doesn't have severe drops or increase in certain objects' quality, thus looking like they'd logically exist in the same setting. =The Audio: 3/5=  The music serves it's purpose decently. The music is nice, without being overly repetitive, and matches the settings quite well. But it's also not the kind of music you'll be finding yourself listening to when not playing the game. The sound effects are nice, and also serve to give a idea on what's in the current scene. There's not much of this employed though, sadly. And I do hope that's addressed in the sequel. =TL;DR/Pros & Cons=Pros- Decent storyline.- Easy to play casual gameplay.- Nicely done graphics that don't look out of place.- Music and sounds that fit the location.- Good amount of Achievements.Neutral- Minimalistic UI is only there when you need it.Cons- Fairly short game.- A bit too casual for those wanting something more from their game experience.- So... Much... Backtracking...=The Conclusion: 6.5/10= A simple game to fill a simple need, Hero of the Kingdom is best suited for the casual gamer, and suits them well. The asthetics and gameplay are well done and serve their purpose. The game is seemingly well crafted despite it's simplistic nature, and doesn't seem to suffer from a lack of quality, inciting that the developer put much love in to this game and didn't make it to purely be a cash grab. Which is nice to see.It's definitely a good game to pick up on sale, which just so happens to be right now as of me writing this. So if the game sounds good to you, it would be a nice thing to pick up for a couple bucks.Thank you very much for taking your time to read my review.

												If:1) You enjoy linear, point & click style games that are heavy on the item finding aspect and...2) You're tired of getting kicked around by more complex, unforgiving games and need a shot in your gaming ego...Give Hero of the Kingdom a look. It's not that it's a bad game, it's just that there simply isn't enough of it.  100%ing the game should take a few hours at most. content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												The game was short and most of the fun was probably searching for all the collectables and the few tedious things here and there which did keep you moving around. It made great use of even old areas to go back and do things as you progressed which a lot of games kind of lack. The game is extremely linear, though there are some optional side quests to complete. Real action is not in this game but the artwork here is what compensates that. The game is only truly playable once. After that you know what's going to happen. Towards the end I had been expecting perhaps a twist but, sadly there was none. Honestly the way the game plays out is definitely different and has a lovely layout and design. I wish there was more too it besides all there was. I finished it in one sitting which was quite nice. I do believe that it's not worth the amount of money it is however. Probably half that. It does require a bit of a patience to really go through it though. All in all it's very simplistic and straightforward. I would say the hardest part about the entire thing would be simply remembering where everything is located when you need more. If not for the fact that it's identical with playthrough two I would have no trouble playing through it again thanks to the pleasant experience I had. If you do decide to give it a shot I highly recommend waiting for a price drop however.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Short version: 85%Hero of the Kingdom mixes turn-based fantasy strategy gameplay with tycoon-like resource management on a strictly casual level. What is remarkable about it is the good balance between the gameplay aspects.Long version:Hero of the Kingdom is a resource management strategy game– something that fits well to the portfolio of the Slovakian development team– with a fantasy adventure theme. The goal is always to gather enough resources to pass the current objective. This requires a careful management of gold (for tools to gather the resources with) and strength (which serves the role of time units). There is no combat or levelling: if you have the resources to pass an obstacle, you automatically do so.The mechanics are decent, but not perfect: there are exploits to get infinite gold and strength (although slowly), and it is easy to get confused by the variety of required resources by the end.The story is fairly basic: find abducted relative, find bad sorcerer, kill bad sorcerer. This simplicity works to its advantage though as it lets the game put more focus on the dozens of side quests, giving it a classic RPG feel. Still, most players will likely reach 100% completion status within 4-5 hours, making Hero of the Kingdom a short, but fun game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												This is exactly the casual adventure with a tiny hint of resource management that gets you to relax after a long day at work.The story is very simple, but thankfully not dumb-simple. The artwork is delightful especially if you're into this sort of 'painted' medieval setting. (think Stronghold, Robin Hood: Legend of Sherwood, HoMaM 3 etc)The soundtrack is heavenly. It's the kind of music that gives you a sense of adventure, yet you still feel like reading a fairy tale while listening to it.The gameplay, as stated, is very casual. Sit back, click, relax. At first it may seem like the game is adamant in showing you how to do every little thing to the point where you're like 'geez, I get it, let me do it alone', but have patience.8/10 - because it's rather short and there's not much replay value. But I still recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												This was one of the better casual games in my collection. It's mostly a point & click adventure with some RPG-like quests and trading built in. I appreciated what depth it did have without having something convoluted or difficult built in just to try to extend the playtime. The story is not complex, and it's fairly typical of this type of game, but it provided enough to give a feel of progression. I completed the game in one sitting as I was completely immersed in it.I'm a big fan of this style of graphics. It has an older Ages of Empires or Stronghold feel to it. I enjoyed going between each area and completing quests just to see what all I'd see. The audio/music complemented the game well. It was just enough to make it enjoyable without being overbearing or out of place.There is some backtracking to be done depending on what the quests require. Not everything is available the first time you visit a zone. The only annoying thing was the "Gather XX of Something" achievements. It just made it a grind and somewhat annoying, especially the eggs. It was like an Easter egg hunt without the color. Even so, I managed to complete the main quest and all of the other achievements within 7 hours.The $5.99 price tag may be questionable for some. Casual is one of my primary game types, and for what this game has to offer, I could see paying it. However, I got this during one of the sales in 2014, and I don't regret buying it. If you're not sure if you should get it now or wishlist it for a sale later, there is a Demo available for you to try.I have purchased Hero of the Kingdom II, so I will be playing that one next!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												6/10I came across this while trying to curb my game expenditure by trawling the depths of the cheapest games on steam and the fact this review (and many of the steem reviews) is positive reflects how cheap/bundled this game often is. It's a simple, short but quite well done little time-killer that might appeal when you are in the mood for something slower.You progress through a series of reasonably pretty full-screen maps. Each one you visit might hold a handfull of missions plus perhaps a merchant, tradesman, somewhere to rest, etc and will definately hide a number of hidden objects to find. Once you unlocked each screen you can return at any time to use the merchants, finish side quests or pick up any hidden objects you missed.The story is standard fantasy fare but is fine. The graphics are ok for a game so much about staring at the screen and set the mood well. The game play is good initially though starts to grate and grind a bit in the later stages even in a comparatively short game. For example consuming food at a camp is essential to gain heart points (used to perform most quests/activities) which is accompanied by a pretty but time consuming little 'nighty night' graphic sequence. Very atmospheric the first couple of times but you need loads of heart points to get through the game and end up spamming the camp sites. It is a game that you cannot really lose - instead you just kind of amble through it... That said, I did finish it... And I did hunt about a bit for the hidden items before finishing the well-flagged final quest... And I paid £0.69 for 5 hours gameplay... Overall that makes it hard not to recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Hero of the Kingdom was a game I had seen around and mentioned occasionally. I saw it for almost nothing during a sale so I grabbed it and went into it basically blind. I have no regrets. I found myself unable and unwilling to hop off the game once I got started and finished it in the same sitting. It took me around 6 hours from start to finish inclusive of all achievements. For an older game with a very basic art / game play style I found Hero of the Kingdom to be a fantastic little adventure even when the story became very cheesy towards the end. Everything requires minimal thought and I breezed through the game satisfied at all times with the progression and events. If I had to point out any flaws I'd say the difficulty and the lack of replay ability. Honestly though, for what I paid I feel as if I've ripped the developers off. It was a great game and worth every penny. If you find yourself in the mood for a simple adventure / RPG / point and click game. Look no further, this game scratches all those itches. 8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Hero of the Kingdom is a point-and-click adventure/resource management game in which you play as a farm boy attempting to discover what happened to your father. You travel around the countryside collecting items and solving various quests in a series of drawn maps. There isn't much in the way of difficulty as there are a few different methods by which you can get as much money as you want, it's just a matter of figuring out your preferred method.There are a number of hidden object quests throughout the game where you search for items in the background. This can be time consuming and is the primary difficult part if you feel like completing it.The game isn't terribly long, taking about 5 hours to complete. But it scratches a zen-like itch for collector/RPG/progress fanatics, and I think you'll get your money's worth if you're into those sorts of games.

												i didn't expect much from this game and i was very pleasantly surprised.the graphics are neat, sound fits in just fine and the music is relaxing as well.obviously it's a casual game. there is no real difficulty at all but the game certainly knows how to keep you busy. and that's no problem at all since it comes with all the quality of life features you need. it even has a map with fast travel so you don't need to curse if you are missing a healing potion or two arrows for your next adventure. even the story is rather decent and the fixed screen resolution isn't such a big deal after all. the game was finished in 4.5 hours and i grabbed all the achievements in the same run. if you feel bored during the weekend or you're sick at home and can't game as hard as usual then it's perfectly fine.if it looks interesting to you and you even take the time to read the reviews then i don't see why you shouldn't enjoy this game as well.

												I like the concept behind this game. Travelling through an environment and saving the world by clicking on parts of it, and I am perfectly fine with it not being the most engaging experience because of it.However, the tasks quickly devolve into grinding up money to allow for the next trivial requirements on the story tasks and the game stopped being much fun well before I finished it.I did finish it though, and even though it wasn't a world-shattering ending it wasn't bad. Things get wrapped up well enough, and after that you can still muck about in the game world doing things you missed.The completionist in me was frustrated that I am still missing a few mushrooms and that there's no indicator what part of the (pretty large) map they're on.It's not a bad game at all, but probably not one I'd have bought in hindsight.Definitely give the demo a try if you like how it looks though.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Great addictive point-and-click game that had me stuck to my screen for a few hours. I found no flaws or bugs to the game, the only thing that I think could've improved the experience would've been more gameplay customization options, less pop-ups, some more info on quest objectives, cause I found myself wandering around trying to find out where I need to go or to look and find something quest related (on this matter some glittering effects over things of interest so you can spot them easily would've helped a lot, but then again this might be intended, as you have to look very careful at everything on screen so you can take advantage of everything given to you). It's all about managing your resources, foraging and all that kind of stuff, but unfortunately has no replayability value and the game lasts for 1-2 hours. I played through it 2 times just to get all the achievements, second time went really fast. Though I have no complaints given the fact that I paid 1$ for it so it was worth.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												I got this game as part of a bundle, and looking at the asking price...it isn't really worth it.-There is very little game play, it is essentially managing resources and clicking all over the screen to find little hidden things.  To call it an RPG makes the original final fantasy look like morrowind.  It is basically one long trading quest, with a couple of little side trading quests. -It is not challenging at all.  I'm not sure if it is even possible to lose.  Maybe, if you were really incompetant you could squander all your resources.  Otherwise there is no tension, you will go into the final battle knowing you will win.-Randomly clicking all over the screen is a legitimate strategy. -The story is absolutely forgettable and generic fantasy,  House burns down, chase after bandits, help villagers, rescue family, defeat big evil.   -Graphics are ok for a cow clicker, but there is no way you are going to be engrossed in the "battles"-It is very short.Beat it in one sitting.  Did I hate it? No.  Will I ever play it again? No.  I get the feeling this game is supposed to be padded out with "freemium" pay to play mechanics. There simply isn't a lot of game here, and I can't reccomend it outside of it being heavily discounted.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												*Click* *Click* *Click* *Click* *Click* Casual game with a rather pale story and some "search those 5 pixels in a picture"-moments. Good game for easy achievments, bad game if you pay more than 2 bucks. Hero of the Kingdom is a point and click adventure mixed with a resource manager. You travel through different overview screens, visiting villages, mountains, forests and so on. On your way, you pick up items either by clicking (said "Search those 5 pixels"-moments) or by buying/trading/questing at NPCs. The more you progress, the more resources you have. For example you need Energy to fight (a boar or wolf costs X energy), which you replenish by sleeping. You can sleep when you pay gold at inns or in the wild, if you have enough food on you (different camping sites ask for different kinds of food). You can also carry items, which hold longer (Weapons and tools, though they might break sometimes)Sadly, the system is kinda broken after a while for those, who notice how to milk endless gold out of the resource cycle. Maybe a patch would help here?The artwork is pretty good, I expect the designer to give us a full course of his abilities in the future. Everything looks very detailed and alive and every screen carries a different kind of atmosphere with it The background music is nothing outstanding, but it doesnt kill the atmosphere either. "Generic" comes to my mind here.Still, seeing as this is an endless orgy of clicking and searching I can not recommend it at its current price of 6 Euro. Maybe some mini-games and riddles would have helped to add simply MORE CONTENT to this game. In the end I just played it to gather all achievments, having absolutely no interest for an ending (and there is only one. Why not make different endings, depending on how you choose to solve quests and stuff? A simple BAD Ending would even give more depth...)

Posted: October 4, 2014
 new experience Well, i did not expect much from this game. But, this game developer pointed the whole gaming industry (and me) how to make a simple but good game. They have created a new genre of RPG (kinda JRPG but not JRPG) and adventure and trading ( a lot like port royal 2) game. This game is easy, enjoyable and has a not awesome but good story. Just buy this game. You don't know what you're missing.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Hero of the Kingdom is a fun little point and click adventure with a slight hidden object element to it. The game has you playing the son of a farmer whose farm gets destroyed by bandits. What happens next is the start of your adventure into this interactive story. The gameplay is pretty basic, but for a casual game its a lot of fun! The fetch quests, and other various side quests are pretty much what you would expect from an RPG game. There are a couple annoying features such as not being able to buy/sell items in bulk, and running out of strength after a couple battles, but this doesn't deter you from enjoying the game. The one feature I would like to see in the sequel is for the collectible hidden object side of the game, they need to add a completion meter for each map so the player is not having to use a magnifying glass to find the last couple of missing items. The game is short and can be completed in about 5 hours if you are trying to 100% the achievements.  If you just play the story its about a 2-3 hr game. Great game for the money! I give this a solid 8/10!

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Nice little game.  One for when you need a rest after a tough day ... sit back enjoy :)Having now completed the game I can say it was a good break from other formats.The game is a story book puzzle with decent background music... very relaxing.It only moves at your pace ... so you can play it whilst on the phone :)  Basically you spot items scattered around the pages of teh map and lcick on them.  As you harvest those items you learn new skills and can see other items.  Some items are rare and can often be made by learning a skill nad combining other cheaper items.  Spotting all those things to harvest is more fun than I thought it would be.  Eventually I found them all adn to get some acheievements I had to earn my way by buying and selling.  You could play this game through fast or you could do what I did.. .I loaded teh  game up whilst I was chatting on the phone [listening and saying stuff like 'hmmm' 'yeh' 'I undersstand' etc :)  yup one of those types of conversation ]   Made the whole conversation more bareable :)  Later I played more for the fun of teh game itself.  Hunting those elusive items to score acheivements was just what I needed when I wasn't feeling well enough to play a more demanding game.

												Summary excerpt from original review post.For full review please visit - http://thewirednomad.com/2017/01/10/hero-of-the-kingdom-review/Hero of the Kingdom is simply a classic bite-sized indie game made by passionate people. Posted: October 30, 2016
												Interactive Folk Art Simulator. If you can get past the old timey graphics, this game is actually quite enjoyable. You pretty much point and click on parts of the area you are in to either (harvest resources, fight, build, buy/sell items). It is slow paced so you can progress at your leasure. One thing most people don't know is that you can actually click on things that do not necesarily have icons over them (ie: mushrooms,eggs,lobsters,crates,wood,rocks, and rarely hidden people). the cheapest method I found for sleeping is to spend 1 bread at the second zone you find. Later you can turn grain in to create flour and turn the flower in to get 6 bread (total cost 35 gold for 6 bread). Also, do not sell stuff you cannot find or harvest regularly, you may have to buy it back. If you ever see on sale for 50% off or more, i would recommend getting this relaxing interactive art book. 10/10 would steal that guys wood again, only to sell it back to him.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Nice little game.  One for when you need a rest after a tough day ... sit back enjoy :)Having now completed the game I can say it was a good break from other formats.The game is a story book puzzle with decent background music... very relaxing.It only moves at your pace ... so you can play it whilst on the phone :)  Basically you spot items scattered around the pages of teh map and lcick on them.  As you harvest those items you learn new skills and can see other items.  Some items are rare and can often be made by learning a skill nad combining other cheaper items.  Spotting all those things to harvest is more fun than I thought it would be.  Eventually I found them all adn to get some acheievements I had to earn my way by buying and selling.  You could play this game through fast or you could do what I did.. .I loaded teh  game up whilst I was chatting on the phone [listening and saying stuff like 'hmmm' 'yeh' 'I undersstand' etc :)  yup one of those types of conversation ]   Made the whole conversation more bareable :)  Later I played more for the fun of teh game itself.  Hunting those elusive items to score acheivements was just what I needed when I wasn't feeling well enough to play a more demanding game.

Posted: January 23
												Summary excerpt from original review post.For full review please visit - http://thewirednomad.com/2017/01/10/hero-of-the-kingdom-review/Hero of the Kingdom is simply a classic bite-sized indie game made by passionate people. Posted: October 30, 2016
												Interactive Folk Art Simulator. If you can get past the old timey graphics, this game is actually quite enjoyable. You pretty much point and click on parts of the area you are in to either (harvest resources, fight, build, buy/sell items). It is slow paced so you can progress at your leasure. One thing most people don't know is that you can actually click on things that do not necesarily have icons over them (ie: mushrooms,eggs,lobsters,crates,wood,rocks, and rarely hidden people). the cheapest method I found for sleeping is to spend 1 bread at the second zone you find. Later you can turn grain in to create flour and turn the flower in to get 6 bread (total cost 35 gold for 6 bread). Also, do not sell stuff you cannot find or harvest regularly, you may have to buy it back. If you ever see on sale for 50% off or more, i would recommend getting this relaxing interactive art book. 10/10 would steal that guys wood again, only to sell it back to him.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												Very nice, very casual point&click adventure RPG, Hero of the Kingdom tells a familiar story of a farmboy turned hero.The wannabe hero begins his journey when bandits burn his family farm down. He gets to do all sorts of jobs from woodcutting to burning to healing wounded people. Gameplay is simple: clicking a marker will give you a short written description (no voice-over here) of your character's thoughts, what you can (and therefore should) do and what you need to accomplish that. You need many kinds of resources in the form of food, vitality, gold and tools.While the gameplay is a casual adventure, you also have to manage the said resources. You'll gain vitality by resting, which requires food that is acquired by foraging or hunting, which in part require tools and skills. Many parts of this chain could have been removed to smooth the gameplay: with them, however, it is an adventure RPG game, not just a barely visual novel.There are also many details in the areas that turn out to be significant later on. Some of them are "hidden", though, meaning that you just have to click them to see if they react: stuff like collectable mushrooms and lootable barrels form this category.The narration is casual and easygoing, containing little to no fancy words. In effect, it would be quite suitable to be played with young children who can't read yet, assuming English proficiency. Like so, the story is rather traditional with the evil dark wizards and all. It's still nice enough to keep in its grip for the while it lasts.Full completion would have lasted about 4 hours, but I went for all the achievements. This added about an hour to the playtime because I just couldn't find several last mushrooms and hidden caches. While challenging, I was irritated to check the same areas ten times just to find those last missing items. Anyway, this is amended, as I really enjoyed the leisure style.Replay value, IMO, is meager though. Once played through completely, there isn't much more to accomplish. That said, it is rather alright an experience for its price.

Posted: January 25, 2016
												I can't say I've ever played a game like Hero of the Kingdom. It's something of an adventure game that gives you a birds-eye view of your surroundings and progresses through some simple mouse clicks. I have a hard time reviewing Hero of the Kingdom, because it's so forgetable. On the other hand, it is quite an enjoyable time-killer. Let me explain. Hero of the Kingdom is about a young man whose farm is burned to the ground--forcing him to journey out into the world to survive. From there the story becomes generic in almost every sense of the word. You'll fight skeletons, beasts and goblins before eventually taking on a dark wizard. While I can see that a lot of love went into this game, the writing could definitely be more original. The gameplay involves a lot of trading. You'll essentially be roaming around the various areas searching for items to sell or animals to hunt so you can get gold with which you can purchase supplies you need to further the story. While I played quite a bit of the game several months ago (I don't remember how long I played, but I remember accidently leaving the game running for a while, so my time played is off) and I didn't manage to get myself to finish it until a couple days ago. For me, the concept of constantly trading like in Hero of the Kingdom becomes tedious. Especially when you unlock every area of the game and it gets tough remembering where certain merchants and points of interest are. I'm afraid I can't give any input on the sound. It wasn't long into the game until I just played my own music over it. Despite all of this, I'm still recommending it. This game is a great time sink. While it did repetitive after a while, the first hours were pretty entertaining. It was actually rather fulfilling to trade my way up to the items I needed. While it's just not a game for me, I can definitely see Hero of the Kingdom appealing to fans of the genre. It was certainly a good time sink for me if nothing else.

												First playthrough took about 4 hours, and I loved it! Easy to 100% if you do everything (turns into a chore) and the second playthrough was complete garbage. 7/10 for the fact that I can't replay it without wanting to an-hero.

Posted: April 5
												Completed after 5 hours.So here're some of my thoughts:PROS:Very rare idea, not first person not third person, it's god mode view.Well mix of point and click and RPGLots of side questsCONS:TOO SHORT! I Played it while I'm working and talking to a friend on FB and I could finish it in 5 hours, I believe I can finish it in just 2 hours if I was very focused, it's the length of a flash game!The game is just too easy after you clear the Old Jack quest, after completing that you can buy fish at 4 bucks each and you can sell them at 6 bucks each in the town. The arbitrage would give you infinite money provided you have the time.It would be nice if there's a saturation of market that the player has to grind on other places for money. But with the current build at the time of writing the player is just GOD as he can has infinite money easily.And in this game money = GOD (Maybe a nice reflection of the real world), you can have many things done instantly if you are ready to pay.That being said, I still recommend this game, it helped refresh my mind during a long working day!

Posted: June 8, 2015
												So glad to finally play a casual game on PC that isn't a mobile port. I would characterize Hero of the Kingdom as a casual adventure game with some trading elements. There are no reflexes required, you simply need to click around the different maps to collect various items and turn them in to complete tasks. When you complete most tasks you beat the game. Overall you shouldn't expect to play this for more than a couple hours but it is a good use of time where you don't need to stress out. I found the story to be serviceable given the scale of the game.All actions in the game are ultimately governed by its currency, which is gold. So if you want to do lots of things, such as stock up on supplies, get more hit points or hire more helpers, you need gold. This is where the trading part of the game comes in. There is only a finite number of resources you can gather before you run out, but you can manufacture more money by astutely trading the resources between various NPCs. I found this to be kind of interesting, but ultimately maybe not that constructive as the game actually gives you a good amount of money. I blame it on my RPG hoarding tendencies, but if you sell everything you gather (and you should! there are no missables!) you should only have to do a minimum of trade farming.Lastly, many people play this game because it is easy to get 100% achievements. Not really my thing, but that could be a reason to play this game as well.

Posted: April 2
												[If you like "Where's Waldo" consider this review with a "yes" recomendation.]RPG for the explorer and item map item seeker:Positives:           1)  The map hunting for items and materials was intriguing and fascinating.         2)  The management aspect (time vs. items) of the game was worthy of compliment.          3)  The story was pleasant.         4)  Side quests were motivational and interesting enough to peak interest in them.On the fence:           1)  Music was acceptable...         2)  The world was interesting...however it was small.         3)  The dialogue is fine, but ... at the same time not all that important.Negatives:         1)  Short (beat it under 5 hours.         2)  Too expensive for such a short game with minimal "replay-ability".         3)  Why is everyone relying on you?   (Are you the only compentent person in the kingdom?)         4)  Too easy... no real skill seems to be required.  (Point and click, point and click, point and click...)         5)  Hunting a boar with a dagger...  NO!   It was stupid in "Lord of the Flies" and it is stupid here.  (For the literature people.)         6)  There is very little choice in this game; so, is it really an exploration game?Overall:  I lacks a lot.  It was a good idea, and the visual scenic hunt is exceptional.  If you like, item hunting games like "Where's Waldo" this would be a good one for you.   Wait until it is on sale (~$2.00).

Posted: July 4, 2014
												For a very casual, simplistic sort of game, Hero of the Kingdom does a good job of entertaining. Yes, there are some things which are like "wha..?" in it, making you wonder what the developer was thinking when they were figuring the game out. Overall, however, this game was well worth the little bit of money I spent on it and was a quite enjoyable 4 hour interlude into it's realm. The story is rather predictable but still good and the point-and-click nature of the game lends itself to being fairly casual, thankfully.7.5/10. Definitely worth a few dollars.

Posted: August 4, 2015
												In Hero of the Kingdom you click on exclamation marks to see a checklist of materials, and then you click on the various icons scattered throughout the map to collect those materials, then you click on the exclamation mark to turn-in those materials.  You will repeat this process for the next 3-4 hours until all the exclamation marks are gone.  Then you win the game.There is no strategy - you simply click what needs to be clicked.  This game is "item management" at its most tedious.There are no role-playing elements - labelling this game as an RPG is inaccurate, even by the loosest of definitions.There is no tension - you cannot fail any of the tasks given to you (which, again, is just gathering materials).There is no story - well, there is, but it's about as generic and shallow as a story can get.There is no gameplay - unless you're the kind of person who thinks moving rocks from one pile to another counts as a "game".I did not hate my time with Hero of the Kingdom, but I did not enjoy it either - it simply felt like I turned my brain off for a few hours and gained nothing from it (besides some trading cards).  If that experience appeals to you, by all means buy this game (on sale).  But if you like games with even a modicum of depth to them, you should look elsewhere.

												Not the game I thought it was, the screenshots made it looks interesting but basically it's a point and click adventure game which has a very linear progression of with virtually no exploration or individuality.Basically you are given a quest and you'll have maybe 3-4 places on the map you can click at any given time. Posted: May 5, 2015
												This game is horribly, poisonously addictive.The idea of the game is to click on certain map hotspots that either advance the plot or give you resources. You can then click on different map hotspots to exchange resources for other resources. This is sometimes puzzle-solving but much more often simply deciding which trade would be more valuable in the long run. I did say "map," and I meant it; you're looking at the Kingdom you are the Hero of from an altitude of a few hundred feet.There's some combat, there are some choices of which path to pursue first, but overall the game is fairly linear and very simple. There's a kind of thin plot involving finding out what happened to your family, but it plays out very slowly. It feels like this was originally a mobile game, and seems especially suited to a touch screen ... though I wouldn't want to read this much text on a screen that size. (Also, there are irritating hidden objects, like mushrooms, scattered around, which are barely visible even on a full-size monitor.)Although it never actually happened to me, it certainly seems like it's possible to get stuck without the resources you need to continue and without any ability to accomplish anything. So there's an element of resource management. Otherwise, though, this is a decidedly mechanical point-and-click game, distinguished only by the UI's bird's-eye view.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. A mix of point and click and adventure with great story that leaves you wanting more with every newely discovered area. There's fishing, gathering and hunting to be done. This is a well paced game with a spot of what I would consider "open world" that branches off into several sidequest that tie in quite nicely with the main story.Pro tip for beginners: When you can buy fruit from the fruit seller, make sure you spend all your available gold on fruit and backtrack to the Farmer's Wife and sell all of your fruit to her. If you do this for a while you'll be able to afford tools, food and other various items you need in the upcoming areas. One reviewer said that he barely had enough money to get to new areas but the whole point of the game is to see it from the character's perspective, he has to go between villages and barter to make a profit to continue on his journey. It's not lazy, it forces you to play the game the way it was meant to be played and not find a loophole past everything.Update: Having completed the game a couple of days ago, I am satisfied with it's ending. All of the loose ends toward the last couple of hours of gameplay finally came together. My only grief with the game is that there wasn't enough clashing during the important end game battles, the sound effects could've been extended a bit longer to emphasize how intense and important they were.I recommend this game for anyone looking for a casual well paced game. The point is to follow the story and be taken on the well told (albeit short journey) of a young man who's on a quest to find his Father while being unknowingly whisked into an age old battle involving the Dark Wizard.

												This was an interesting game that I found oddly addicting. Most of the gameplay takes place in small areas, one area for each overworld location and the player clicks on events within each area. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
Hero of the Kingdom is a slightly unusual mix of point-and-click adventure and rpg. It looks like an old-school isometric rpg, but there is no character to control - instead all actions are performed by clicking on object like in a point&click title. The basic rpg premise is still here (slight spoilers!) - an ordinary boy on a quest to find his father turns into a hero that saves the land from dire evil. Yeah, like no one expected that, spoilers over. The boy learns skills during the adventure - hunting, herbalism, etc - in order to get closer to his goal. As if the mix wasn't unusual enough the game adds in some Hiden Object elements - there are treasures and extra items hidden around in the bushes, rivers, barrels. Visually the game has nothing to be shy of, it's a simple but well drawn style. Map elements are clearly distinguishible and even the hidden items are fairly easy to spot with a little practice. It's overall easy on the eye even for longer sessions. The audio is pleasant enough too, can't say much in detail about it personally but at least it feels right. Sadly, there is very little, if any, voice acting and that might diminish the enjoyment for some players - while lots of detailed text and dialogues can be enrich the world it might also bore the player.Personally I find the mix pretty entertaining, then again I enjoy casual games so take what I say with a grain of salt. Nevertheless, the story moves at a good enough pace to keep boredom away and it's easy to enjoy this in bite-sized portions if so desired. Time-wise the game takes around 5 hours for a relaxed playthrough, dipping to maybe 3-3.5 for a speedy run and climbing to approx 8 for a single 100% run. At L5 that is pretty good value for anyone who likes a more casual adventure. tl;dr: At £5 it's a good mix of point&click, adventure, and casual gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												I actually take a fairly neutral stance on this game, but for the sake of leaving a review I lean towards 'recommend.'Pros:  The artwork is beautifully done and the navigation layout isn't bad.  Although the storyline is a bit hackneyed, I still found myself getting into it.  The text based narration was decent and the sound effects were well done.  Finding all the hidden goodies throughout the game felt like a flashback to Where's Waldo books.Cons:  Don't expect a lengthy game!  I beat it twice in under 10 hours for all the achievements.  The entire game only encompasses a small group of tiles, so not much exploring.  The harvesting can be tedious when combined with the constant need to rest and exchange for supplies.  Most of the harvesting is only used to monotonously build up money instead of crafting or building.If you're looking for a game to relax and kill a few evenings, it will do well.  The game has so much potential but it just stops far short.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												"Eh" -- This was how I felt after completing this game. My best assessment would be it is one part hidden object game, one part story. I am even hard-pressed to call it a "Game" because it's so linear and the only real "skill" to it is being comprehensive in clicking everywhere and making sure you have enough gold to accomplish the next task. I would have enjoyed the game better if combat was not all automatically a success as long as you brought the right materials (and you aren't even allowed to initiate combat without said materials, so where is the fun in that?) ... I mean, include SOMETHING that requires decision-making, or strategy, or twitch skills... otherwise it's just another step in a procedure. Still, I am leaving a positive recommendation because obviously it was compelling enough for me to finish it... but there are a great many better RPGs out there. I have no regrets playing it though.

												This amazing game was definately worth it's price!Hero of the Kingdom is point'n'click fabular game. You live on a small farm away from the civilization - suddenly your father was kidnapped by bandits. You have to rescue him, and... You'll see by your own! :)Story was quite good. This game's story is more for a children than an adult, but i enjoyed it. It's really simple. like in classical point'n'click you have to click on terrain to find hidden treasures, or get resources. There are also some interesting side quests with ghosts and more. There are 3 skills - Alchemy, Hunting and Fishing, and nothing more - that's not RPG game with all those stats. What's more, you can buy and sell some stuff, and do some simple side quests. game is for 2-4 hours. The biggest con was unsophisticated story - and that's all. As i said on the start, game was worth it's price and I reccomend it to every point'n'click and medieval fan!

												At first glance this probably doesn't look like very much.  It might be confusing as to what type of game it is.Despite being tagged by many as an RPG, this is definitely an adventure game.  It isn't very dialogue heavy but the storyline is more than sufficient, and although it is essentially linear, it cleverly gives the illusion of not being so.  It is longer than you might expect, and tracks the story of a young boy  on his journey to save his father.  It's fairly generic, but the style of the game is rather unique, so this is easily forgiven.Be careful- you might read elsewhere online that you can get achievements after you complete the game by continuing.  This isn't true.  I found this out the hard way and will have to get the rest when I  play it again someday.  I can't judge the developer for this, though.

												Fun, relaxing game. Definitely no brain-drain here. Maybe a slight bit of tedium if you want to stockpile the money and tools. For instance, I buy grain, go down 2 maps to have it ground then back up to turn it into bread then down four maps to sell them to the farmer's wife. But that's just the OCD'er in me. Probably unnecessary since there's plenty of things to gather that you can sell. I was just always afraid I'd sell off things that might be needed in one of the fetch quests later.That's pretty much the game; Story-driven RPG element fetch quests and hidden objects. If you don't like those two gameplay elements then pass on this. If you're okay with them then this is a definite buy at this price, because you will be kept busy and entertained.Good music, nice scenery, nice story, laid-back gameplay. The perfect relaxing game to sit down with either with your morning coffee, or to unwind after a long day at work or school.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Hero of the Kingdom is a game, I'd probably describe as a light, casual point’n’click-hidden-object-RPG-adventure, which happens to be surprisingly addicting.It's basically a simple game, in which you click on certain hotspots on the map to interact with your environment (for example shopkeepers to buy or sell items, a camp to restore some stamina or quest-npcs to start or finish the main- or one of several sidequests) and move yourself through about 25 screens of a nice-looking medieval world, advancing in a (shallow and not really innovative) story of a boy from a farm saving his father and becoming a hero at the end.While you basically always do the same thing (just click on things), the objectives you have to fulfill are actually pretty diverse. Sometimes you have to kill stuff (animals, villians), find things hidden-object-style (eggs, mushrooms, sheep) or collect (and/or buy) the right resources to build buildings or equip an army. There are even some professions to master (fishing, herbalism).Still these things are so simple, that literally anyone could succeed to finish the game in a reasonable time. Optionally you can also try to collect all 38 achievements, which include finding a big portion of all hidden-object items.Unfortunately, even if you try to 100% the game, it only takes about 3-4 hours to do so. But that might even be a good thing, because otherwise the simple gameplay could get boring and repetetive after some time.Also you have to know, what you’re getting with this game. If you’re expecting a much deeper, complex game, the game will most likely disappoint you. But fortunately there is a demo available to test the game and see if it is for you.Overall, I think, this is an awesome game, that can be fun for ANYONE: Casual players as well as actual ‘gamers’, who don’t mind simple gameplay and a shallow story, can enjoy an addicting medieval adventure with a decent atmosphere. Granted: The game might be short, but the price isn’t to high (6$), especially on sale. I encourage everyone to give this one a try (at least the demo)!On a scale from 1 to 10 I’d give this one an 8.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Hero of the Kingdom is a hybrid between an RPG and a casual resource-management game. From the outlook, you may think it's like an old-school RTS, like I did. Reminds me of Stronghold.Once you go into it, you'll realize that it's nothing of the sort.Basically, you travel around the land, buying, gathering and selling supplies, so that you can progress, by doing quests. It's... surprisingly compelling. On paper, I'd say this game wouldn't work! After trying it, though, it managed to keep me playing to completion. There's an overarching story, but it's very cliché. It did nothing whatsoever to invest me, as there weren't any great characters or situations. It was just there.PresentationAs I said, it looks a bit old. However, I really like this graphic style. I love the way the how old RTS games looked, and this is basically an higher resolution version of that. The iconography in the game felt a bit out of place, at times, but it identifies everything well enough, so I won't complain.Other than that, the interface has a medieval feeling (especially the frames and the map) that fits the feeling of the game.The sound-effects were a bit too sparkly for me. They didn't fit the rest of the game, being more suited for a children's game, with a cartoony look. Regardless, they're otherwise functional.The music is open, I believe, but it was well chosen. There isn't much to say about it. It's pretty simple, fantasy-like background music, but it did its job of getting you into the game's atmosphere.There were a few interface issues I've had, but I've later found out that most of them could have been avoided, with a bit more explanation. Basically, everything requires 2 clicks -- always. First, you click the objective or object you want to collect, and then there's some feedback, and a box appears with a "V" for you to click, to continue. This last step, in my opinion, was completely unnecessary. Also, the box appears in the object's place, so you'll often have to "backtrack" with the mouse, if you were ready to leave the screen, or something. This is avoided by pressing SpaceBar when the box appears. That way, you can just press it and the box will go away, so it partially solves the problem -- this, however, was never hinted at, in the game.Overall, there are just lots of unnecessary clicks, in a game that's all about clicking. I believe that the visual and audio feedback was sufficient, but I may be wrong.Story and WritingAs I've mentioned, the story is completely cliché. Your farm burns, and you go on a quest to save your father and be an hero. Then, you find that there's a bigger evil on the world, and you want to eliminate it. That's about it. There's isn't any real idea to be trasmitted by it, no interesting characters, nothing whatsoever. Bottom-line: don't play it for a story.The writing also felt very amateur, in general. The game just feels like it could be written by a middle-schooler. It's not awful, but there's nothing, at any point, that will surprise you or even amuse you. The phrasing is very simple, with not character having any personality... Meh. You can easily skip it and you won't miss anything.Structure & MechanicsIt's hard to separate this from the mechanics. This game is a glorified spreadsheet, and it's almost all structure, and no mechanics.Basically, you have a character whose main attribute is stamina. You lose stamina with every meaningful action, and you'll have to sleep on a camp to recover it. There are many camps spread around the map, requiring different resources for you to use them. Some are town inns, which require money, others will simply require different types of food.Then, you'll also visit several towns that specialize in different things. There's alchemy, fishing, hunting, etc. Each requires different tools, which the townsfolk sell you. In those towns, there are also side-quests, that give you money, honor, and resources.Honor is basically used for you to unlock certain quests, that require you to be more trust-worthy.Despite the existence of several different occupations, they're all the same. Once you have a tool and skill (that you get from a quest), the maps will now have a new icon over the resource that you can gather. Then, you click it and there you go. There's no crafting per se. There are some vendors that give you a potions for herbs though, for example.Each action will require tools/resources, and stamina. Some of them also require Hunters, Repair-men, Soldiers, etc. You can buy these (as if mercenary) to help you. As you can tell, the whole game is about getting resource X and either selling or trading it for resource Y, so that you can do the next quest.Hidden-objects ComponentIn every map, there are items spread around, but that are very small and often blend with the background. These are mostly optional, but they can also be useful. These include Mushrooms, Eggs, Lost Crates, etc. These won't be unlocked from the start, you'll unlock them progressively, when following the main quest.Map The maps tells you nothing useful, but let's you fast travel to every location. So, instead of having to waste 2 minutes and 15 clicks, you'll waste 10 seconds and 2 clicks.This is fine, and I think it helps the game substancially. However, it could have been much better. Has different areas have different vendors and quests, it would have been useful to have those marked on the map. Perhaps a little quest description and the person who gave it to you, the main vendors, etc. You can very easily get lost, since you take to memorize everything. Cumbersome systemsEverytime you gather a resource, hunt, etc. you'll lose stamina, and also have a chance to break your tools. If that happens, you'll have to go buy another. Eventually, I just bought every tool twice to avoid backtracking. However, it's very cumbersome, in general. Especially with the later tasks, everything may cost up to half of your stamina. So, you'll travel, do 2 minor things, and have to go back and get more stamina. I think it's mostly unnecessary, how you constantly have to go back and forward... It never lets go of your hand -- Too LinearThe tutorial is very typical of mobile games. You have to click this very specific icon, or else you can't advance. This goes on for a while. While the game opens up a bit, it's also holding you hand. If I had focused only on the story line, it would have bored me to death, probably. It's like the game tells you its story through instructions. "Do this. Now, do that. Good, now get that to achieve this! No, no that-- this! Here! This shiny button!" ... It's very, very restrictive. The sidequests help a bit.Regardless, it's never an adventure of your own.Progress and AchievementsThis is the trick about this game. There's an achievement for every meaningless task. It's annoying and patronizing. However, it's one of those psychological tricks that keeps you invested. Everything feels like progress. Also, every field will disappear after being gathered "x" times, so there will come a point when you've literally completed the game. And I think that's the strangely compelling thing about this game!It keeps you going for far longer than I'd have guessed. The game has nothing interesting about it, but it still grabs your attention, for those 3 hours!I would not recommend this game, in most circumstances. It's very bland, and has nothing interesting about it. However, it's still compelling. Besides, it provides a good formula. If you can integrate a good story, and some mechanics into it, perhaps a great game can be made!Please, be very aware of what you're getting into. For what it is, it's good!

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Hero of the Kingdom is a wonderful little light RPG disguised as a Hidden Object style game. While undeniably linear, the world is beautifully serene and I actually found myself just leaving the game running as a desktop.The entire adventure takes place from a satellite style view and on each screen of the world there are different activities, shops and quests to do. In addition to the obvious activity bubbles, there are also unmarked collectibles hidden throughout the world. These items for the most part are just another source of income but some also are part of crafting recipes. Everything is as simple as point and click, but rather than being boring it helps to keep the game from overstaying its welcome. The art and sound design is nearly flawless, with my only gripe being a strange soundtrack switch that happens occasionally when navigating through sections of the world and anything faster than a leisurely stroll.The “campaign” in its entirety will only set you back a few hours, but I think it is well worth it for how much detail and care went into this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												I started Hero of the Kingdom without any idea of what it was going to be about. I bought it at a good sale price, the single screenshot I saw looked nice, and I don't like to spoil myself with trailers or large numbers of screenshots going into a game. I was immediately put off, thinking that it was going to be an extremely boring hand-holding hidden object adventure. I'm not fond of hidden object games in general, and I hadn't really been expecting to play one when I started. I wasn't actually wrong in my initial impression--Hero of the Kingdom is a really user-friendly point and click adventure with hidden object elements. The thing about this game, though, is that it is the best casual point and click adventure. The game is beautiful, the music is both relaxing and adventurous (and a true pleasure to listen to), and the sound effects feel crisp and fit just right. Tons of polish all around, and you can tell that there was a lot of love put into making this game. Don't go in expecting to find a particularly detailed story, but what is there is enjoyable as well. Again, very simple, but it feels right. This is a game you can enjoy in small pieces, or devour all at once for a relaxing evening. Sometimes it's nice to play something simple and pleasant. Also, the main character solving a lot of problems by being a pretty decent carpenter was oddly refreshing. It's a skill that doesn't really get a lot of serious recognition even in crafting types of games, and it's handled so reasonably and practically within the confines of the story that I couldn't help but smile at moments like finishing construction of the water mill.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Hero of the Kingdom is a short point-and-click adventure in a fantasy setting.  The player begins as a farmboy and goes on an adventure by essentially completing errands by interacting with various hotspots on a beautifully drawn map.  More screens are unlocked as one progresses through the story.  In addition to the main story, there are various hidden objects such as mushrooms or lost crates scattered throughout the game world.  These objects blend in well enough that they are not all immediately spotted, but if you should choose to find them all, it's by no means a pixel hunt.Someone looking for an extremely non-challenging and casual gaming experience may enjoy this title.  In fact, I somewhat enjoyed it as something to do while watching television.However, I am unable to recommend this game because of its incredibly short length.  I was able to 100% the game in about four hours. Most of those four hours were spent backtracking.  For instance, while fishing, you may run out of energy.  You must then backtrack to the inn to rest.  You then return to the lake to continue fishing, and you run out of bait.  You must then backtrack to purchase more bait.  And then your rod breaks.  You get the idea.In short, Hero of the Kingdom is not all bad by any means.  It's a decent little game that looks and sounds good, even if it is simplistic.  However, the writing is not so hot.  Unless you are absolutely in love with the genre, there's almost certainly better and more fulfilling ways of spending your time.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This is a casual Resource Management game. I mean casual by both slow-paced and easy to beat.The Good :- Simple, Relaxing gameplay.- Resource Management. It's one of my loved genre, but there isn't much games focused on that.- More and more things interactable on maps as you progress.- Lots of bonus loots hidden everywhere, for extra coins.- Map interface allowing you to travel anywhere you've been. It's helpful as you'll be travelling everywhere.The Bad :- Remember, this is NO RPG or STRATEGY. All about handling resources and clicking tiny hidden things.- One playthrough's enough for all achievement. 3 hours for me to get them all.- Management gets too easy once you found out a way to make money.- You never know when you don't need tools anymore(Resource nodes will decay in one or two gathers, and are limited. But don't worry that you can BUY resources from NPCs)- Interaction effects. I'd really love to skip them.- Bulk purchase option needed. It's tiresome to click hundred times when shopping.6/10, Well worth the price, but not too great. And they're making the sequel so I'd like to play it as well.比較的スローペースで簡単な、資源管理ゲー。良い点：・シンプルで遊びやすく、必要なアイテムはアイコン表示なので英語力もそれほど必要ではない。・資源管理の楽しさ。ストラテジー以外でその辺を重視したゲームってあまりない。・進行に合わせてマップ中にあるインタラクト可能なオブジェクトが増えるので、何度か立ち寄って変化を見に行くのが楽しめる。・各所に隠されたボーナスアイテム。・ファストトラベル可能な地図。相当な頻度でマップを移動することになるのでありがたい。悪い点：・RPG要素も戦闘要素も無く、ただ資源を消費・獲得したり、小さなオブジェクトを探してクリックするだけ。・リプレイ性はなく、1週で全実績が取れる。・金策手段を見つけると、(時間はかかるが)一気にゲームが簡単になる・いつツールが不要になるか分からない(リソースノードは1，2回調べると無くなるため有限だが、足りないなら店でいくらでも買える)・インタラクト時のエフェクト。何十回もキャンプで休息してると昼夜エフェクトを飛ばしたくなる。・NPCとの取引で大量購入/売却するオプションが欲しい。何百回もクリックする必要があるのは困る。スコア6/10、定価分は楽しめるとは思う。続編が開発中なのでやりたい。

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												One of the negative reviews calls this an RPG for people who hate RPGs, which isn't unfair, but also isn't necessarily a bad thing. The story is an archetypal (read: generic) WRPG, but with casual gameplay based on gathering resources to earn money and solve quests. For combat, you're required to gather certain weapons, health potions, allies, etc., but you don't actually play through the combat itself, and there's no risk of losing or death.Recommended for fans of hidden object games and the exploration parts of isometric RPGs. Not recommended if you're looking for an actual RPG.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Just finished this game with 100% achievments at around 5 hours. I know that doesn't seem like a lot of time but i do think its a fair amount for how the game actually plays. I mean how much time is taken up in RPGs just buy running for example.I thoroughly enjoyed this game and found it quite cute, and the bartering system was real cool as well. Finding ways to make money to buy the things needed to progress, giving you multiple options of how to acquire the gold, and some items, was cool as well.The story is a nice twist on the classic save the world hero theme and captured me from the start.Like a lot of other people, upon first look it looked like a cheesey facebook game, but i listened to the positive reviews that it is an actual game and it was definitely worth it.Im not a fan of Hidden Item games but the way it is implimented into this one makes the game more enjoyable.The soundtrack also matches the game and sets the scenes nicely.All of this adds up to be a nice non linear-ish chill adventure game that is a great addition to anyones library whether or not you want to slam it out in 4-6 hours flat, or do multiple 30min sessions after long days before bed time like I did.I do think $7 is an alright price to pay, though I do think $5 is more appropriate, i guess it depends how much you get out of playing it and how long it takes. If it took 7 hours, thats $1 for an hour, and not bad, if it took 3.5 hours, thats $2, still not bad.I got this on sale for probably $4-5 and i think it was worth.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Just finished it in 5 hours, so for total game time, I'd say that's pretty much the time it takes to finish the game, and all the achievements. That being said, shows a bit of replayability value. there isn't much to do once you're done. completely. Finish the last achievements, find some more mushrooms, sleep with meat a few more times, and trade until you have 5000 gold in total. But, it's like finishing a pokemon game completely. Finding all the pokemon, and levelling them to the max. Restarting the game from scratch seems like a waste to the time it took, and the story/adventure won't change much.Graphic wise, it's quite good. Not too new of a graphics, but how all areas have small hidden things, like hidden pearls, and mushrooms in them (that you sometimes unlock by becoming a better herbalist) makes each area new, and abundant!The story itself isn't too impressive. but it's fun, and not only can you quite often start doing side quests, and unlock special areas, you can also continue the story, and 2 screens further, another small bit of story is available, so almost all screens have a special story part. This means it's easily focussable on the next challenge, and you won't get lost in the quests and finding the solutions.Gameplay: Gameplay in this game is what really drives the game itself forward. A lot of items that are clickable do not have an actually specific picture, like the trader, or a quest giver does. Sometimes, it's just a simple mushroom in the middle of a forest, that you can click. This means sometimes, boredly looking around actually rewards you. The actual movements aren't great, but it's kind of fun to see soldiers changing position, a few arrows all pointing towards a single enemy, and then moving on. Also, even though you're probably the same size as a normal npc in the game, the fact that you don't see yourself on screen kind of helps the immersion. YOU are the one that checks out the little clearing in the forest, to see if you can help save the lumberjack, and you are the one that decides to attack the boar. Strangely enough, if you would be a few pixels on the screen, you'd be too small to matter, but now, you really do.Basically, I recommend it. I think since it's not too high in replayability, it's probably better to wait for a sale, but there's no definitive need for it. It's just a fun little game, that you can enjoy, until you're completely done.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Good casual game.  Reasonable story doled out in small parcels makes you want to read it and gets you involved in the game.   It's pretty easy but not simplistic - you have to pay attention to the screen.  The hardest achievements are the egg/lost barrel and mushroom collections - these items are very tiny and tend to blend into the background which is why you have to pay attention.  There's a resource management aspect to the game (not hard to manage) and a series of "mini fetch quests" for the most part, again fairly easy.You would think a game littered with "easy fetch this and fetch that" would be boring/tediuos.  This game has managed to strike a nice balance.  Just when it starts to get tedious the game ends.  Buy it on sale.  One play through is about 6 hours.  There's no replayability.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												A very casual resource management game.  Picked this up in a bundle and decided to install and play based on the art and was completely surprised by it.  I thought after clearing the initial area the tutorial-esque prompts would lessen, but no, not really, it's basically how the game works.Most of the game is based on needing x amount of item a,b,c to accomplish z.  This sounds boring and repetitive, but for some reason, I really enjoyed it.  Maybe it was the art direction or how low-taxing it is, but I played this for like a half and hour on my first start-up and then spent the next day waiting to get home to play it again.  It's a short game and I think I finished it over the next two days.  There was something chill and captivating about this game and I really enjoyed despite it being very simple in design and execution.  The English translation can also be awfully stiff at times.I think most people would find this game boring, but I definitely enjoyed this and will probably pick the sequel that is currently in the works when it comes out.  Maybe the casual pastoral resource management genre is my thing.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This is a casual Resource Management game. I mean casual by both slow-paced and easy to beat.The Good :- Simple, Relaxing gameplay.- Resource Management. It's one of my loved genre, but there isn't much games focused on that.- More and more things interactable on maps as you progress.- Lots of bonus loots hidden everywhere, for extra coins.- Map interface allowing you to travel anywhere you've been. It's helpful as you'll be travelling everywhere.The Bad :- Remember, this is NO RPG or STRATEGY. All about handling resources and clicking tiny hidden things.- One playthrough's enough for all achievement. 3 hours for me to get them all.- Management gets too easy once you found out a way to make money.- You never know when you don't need tools anymore(Resource nodes will decay in one or two gathers, and are limited. But don't worry that you can BUY resources from NPCs)- Interaction effects. I'd really love to skip them.- Bulk purchase option needed. It's tiresome to click hundred times when shopping.6/10, Well worth the price, but not too great. And they're making the sequel so I'd like to play it as well.比較的スローペースで簡単な、資源管理ゲー。良い点：・シンプルで遊びやすく、必要なアイテムはアイコン表示なので英語力もそれほど必要ではない。・資源管理の楽しさ。ストラテジー以外でその辺を重視したゲームってあまりない。・進行に合わせてマップ中にあるインタラクト可能なオブジェクトが増えるので、何度か立ち寄って変化を見に行くのが楽しめる。・各所に隠されたボーナスアイテム。・ファストトラベル可能な地図。相当な頻度でマップを移動することになるのでありがたい。悪い点：・RPG要素も戦闘要素も無く、ただ資源を消費・獲得したり、小さなオブジェクトを探してクリックするだけ。・リプレイ性はなく、1週で全実績が取れる。・金策手段を見つけると、(時間はかかるが)一気にゲームが簡単になる・いつツールが不要になるか分からない(リソースノードは1，2回調べると無くなるため有限だが、足りないなら店でいくらでも買える)・インタラクト時のエフェクト。何十回もキャンプで休息してると昼夜エフェクトを飛ばしたくなる。・NPCとの取引で大量購入/売却するオプションが欲しい。何百回もクリックする必要があるのは困る。スコア6/10、定価分は楽しめるとは思う。続編が開発中なのでやりたい。

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												This isn't by any means a bad game, but it doesn't really have much going for it, either. This feels like a point-and-click adventure, where the only thing you can click is progression (or a collectible). For me, at least, the point of point-and-click games is puzzling your way through it, rather than mindlessly clicking whatever bright gold sparkly icon shows up next on the screen. The little hidden object collectibles are interesting, and I think probably the thing that kept me playing the longest, since they respawn after enough time has passed.I would like to acknowledge that the music in this is actually pretty fantastic, though. There are definitely a few things about this game that are amazingly well implemented (fast travel through that map? THANK YOU), and while this feels like a completed game, it just doesn't feel very compelling. The stilted dialogue doesn't help, either. Especially when the boy is all "I have to revenge my father!" That may have been the deciding factor for my not recommending this, actually.

												Well, I beat the game with every achievement there is in about 5 hours. It is a bit tedious from time to time, the story is forgettable and it is a facebook game a la farmville without the additional waiting time. I still enjoyed it enough to finish it. But I also didn't payed full price and received it as part of a bundle. If you're looking for a game where you don't have to think and just need to klick on a few things and search some pictures for mushrooms and treasures, it's most certainly a good pickup. Tune in your favorite podcast and get lost in thoughts. I still wouldn't recommend it for the full price since it's just not entertaining enough for 7 bucks. On sale, yes, normal price, I wouldn't buy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Some simple stuff in this game: Gather this and that, trade this for that, keep a lookout for hidden objects in the scenery, rest when necessary; yet it never really grows old on you.I don't know what else to say really, it's a surprisingly addictive game. And even though the main gameplay consists of gathering, trading and doing quests, the inclusion of some objects hidden cleverly in plain view makes for a game that keeps you engaged.The story is pretty standard, but it's not bad by any means. And whether or not you're into the tropes of RPGs, the simple beauty of the graphics will certainly sway you.I don't know why it's so charming, but I don't care really. This is a good game. And it's certainly worth five dollars. But if you're unsure, get it on a sale. If you like these kinds of games, you'll not regret it.Edit::I still recommend this game for its simple charm, but I should warn you that it's a very casual game. I managed to beat it in about three and a half hours, and earn the remaining achievements in 15 minutes. Granted, I'm the kind of guy who used to pick up Dark Souls and play it casually, so take from that what you want. Still, my point stands: This is a fairly easy game. But that doesn't make it bad. So again: Still recommended.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												This game can be a bit confusing and even boring at the beggining but after you play for a while and start to figure out how the mechanics goes it can surely become very interesting. The story itself is pretty classic, there's not exceptional to be added. Either way, it's enough to keep you motivated to carry on. As for the gameplay, I guess I'd call it a "resource manager RPG", especially because most of the time you need to go after this or after that in order to complete the given quests that are required to advance further on the story. The graphics are ok and the soundtrack can get old after a while so it's not a bad idea to have your own playlist available. There're also the trading cards and the achievements, so it's needless to say that it brings some added value. Overall, if you enjoy the casual genre, this title is for you.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												This is one serious time-sink in veins of every Facebook game ever. You're shown static images where you get to click stuff to get more stuff to divide into other stuff. And clickety-effing-clickety I went. Something like 100 minutes of pure clicking. Damn. I clicked a wood pile and got wood. I clicked a broken fence and the wood was gone. I couldn't see "me" there so I believe the player is some sort of all mighty God that only needs to click to get♥♥♥♥♥♥done. World was just different areas for me since gods move with golden arrows from the edge of areas. I killed animals for their meat and then rested using that meat. When I clicked some people hey asked for help and I freaking delivered! Apples for ♥♥♥♥♥es? Sure, done. Flowers for the old hag? Consider it done. Arrows for Legolas, already there. Flour needed? Please. I found boxes under the water since apparently trashing is a real thing in fantasy worlds. Click. Click click.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												“Ugh another lame indie game” is the same thought that crosses my mind every-time I open something like Hero of the Kingdom; so needless to say I'm more than mildly surprised when I realized this game wasn’t just tolerable but actually slightly addictive. The simplicity and grindyness was just enough to keep me moving through the game, despite the fact that the story was equally simply and grindy. Really the only way to describe Hero of the Kingdom is an RPG with the most streamlined approach you could imagine without being Press Space RPG. Its really only good for one play-through; the $5.99 price-tag is on the high end of what its worth, buy I wouldn’t hesitate to drop $1 to $4 on this game. Definitely worth a shot if you have the addictive RPG looting mentality.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Hero of the Kingdom is a point-and-click role-playing game.  It's more casual and story-driven than the average role-playing game.  It is well-written and comes together naturally.  After this game you could buy the sequel that's similar but has a different character and storyline.  Since the game is more casual, you have plenty of time to make decisions.  I recommend it for people looking for a relaxing, story-driven role-playing game or someone that wants to try something different in the role-playing genre.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												This is one of those casual games that has just enough complexity to keep a child of eight years entertained. It's pretty much a clickfest with a "I'm a farmboy and I must save my dad!" story. No real 'combat' or 'crafting', just 'Make sure you have enough things to do the thing before you try the thing'. There's a little bit of "hidden object" gameplay thrown in as well, and as small as these objects are, they still pop out well enough if you know what you're looking for.It's short, it's sweet, it's not-perfectly translated from Slovak. Buy it if you have kids, or even for yourself if you're suffering from just the teensiest bit of MMORPG ennui.
