content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												From the looks of it, I expected some sort of uninspired Sacred-clone in this game. Instead, I found a little gem of low level fantasy, I happily advise to anyone who likes the genre. Your young hero's task is not to save the world, but to wander the homesteads around his (okay, some clichées are hard to avoid) burned home to rescue his father.In a game, that would be best described as ressource management, you'll find yourself in a mundane atmosphere of people and a world, that don't necessarily turn around you. The gameplay can be broken down to "use thing A to complete task B", plus a bit of hidden object finding. Nothing too challenging, but on the other side nothing that's too distracting from the nice atmosphere, the game creates.Hero of the Kingdom is a refreshing casual experience, I hereby want to recommend.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This is a fun and relaxing game where you follow a young boy on his quest to find his dad after some bandits burned down your farm. On the way you will help others and get rewarded with gold and knowledge, that help you gather and use the resources of the land. On the way you will become the Hero the Kingdom needs.Its a basic click and point game, but it has a nice charm to it. It reminds me a lot of how I saw on adventure and heroes growing up. I played Hero of the Kingdom II before I got my hands on Hero of the Kingdom and its about the same game. Since I liked the Hero of the Kingdom II I was happy. I played for 4 hours and got all the achievements. Pick it up if you want a game that everyone with a basic knowledge of english can enjoy. Only negativ is that the last few eggs and mushrooms are hard to find, so I spent about half an hour on that.

												Good: - Actually pretty fun - Graphics are real nice, and as simple as they need to be - Not too grindy at all, but not easy enough to be boring - CheapBad: - Not really long, 100% achievements in 3.5 hours without a guide - Story is boring, so I skipped all dialogue (personal opinion, nothing against the game) - Not really an overview of what the point is or where I'm aiming for. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game looks like nothing or your typical everyday facebook game, but in fact it's quite funny to click through the story and unfold your own story by fullfilling tasks, killing enemies or just go fishing. What's most enjoyable is your total freedom what or when to do the things you want to do. There is a storyline under all these things but you can freely choose what or what not to do to get to the end. You could even don't care for the story at all and just go hunting in the woods or become a herbalist or fisherman.On top of that there are different objects hidden in the very detailed landscapes that can be found like mushrooms, garbage or different kinds of loot, even treasures can be found. Again it's up to you if you want to go searching for these things or doing something else.If you're not sure how to rate this game then download the demo and give it a chance. I think it's worth the money. When it's on discount for e.g. 4,99 € I recommend you to buy this indie gem.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												Hero of the Kingdom is a mix of different genres, RPG, Hidden Object, Clicker, Point and Click, and it doesn't go into any depth for any of them, yet, the formula seems to work, as I sat down and played through it in one sitting without losing interest.You play a farmer's son who needs to go on a quest to rescue your father after an encounter with bandits. As you explore, more of the map opens up, you discover crafting, magic, and the ability to level up, none of these is in any depth however, and the toughest challenge you will face is managing your economy, as most quests require objects that more often than not, require gold to obtain. So exploring whether or not hunting, herb gathering, fishing, delivery services etc. are enough to earn a profit is about the only learning curve in the game. Many resources are hidden within the world, giving it a slight hidden object vibe, but they aren't very difficult.The graphics are good for the type of game it is, the music fits the theme, and the hours role by. Rather than playing the game for a challenge, you play the game for the story or for the satisfaction you get from completing quests and checking them off your list. Hero of the Kingdom offers casual, stress-free gameplay, and is worth the journey.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												A game seemingly about resource gathering and such, in which you can't gather resources except for a very few scripted places. In the tutorial the game asks you to chop down some trees with your axe to obtain wooden planks – standard stuff. But after that, the only option to get them is to BUY them – despite travelling through large forests.The gold/inventory management is also an illusion, because you always have just enough total money to buy some required items and proceed. Even when you join the army, you have to buy your own weapons and armour. This is a capitalist's wet dream.You basically click through the whole game and you can't deviate from the current objective or you'll get stuck with not enough money and no way to earn more (not that the game gives you such freedom anyway).It's all just incredibly lazy. Even some visual novels seem to have more gameplay. Stay away.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												Bought this via a game bundle, finished in 4 hours, collected all achievements.If you have several hours to kill and want something pretty casual and like me, collect achievements, then get this game. Posted: July 21, 2014
												If you're looking for an extremely casual game then you're in the right place.  It's a basic point and click RPG whereas you're a Farmer's son asked to look after the farm while he leaves to take care of business.  Of course tragedy occurs after a day, or so of your Father leaving the farm. You are forced to travel out into a strange and unfamiliar world with your simple farming equipment to help you along your way to Heroism.The difficulty of the game is simply where to find what, or how to get what in the game and the balancing of money vs. resources. If you need a specific resource and don't have enough tools to farm it, you can buy it for a price naturally. *hint* the resources of this game is limited, so don't sell it all off if you don't need to. I've made a complete game walkthrough with 100% achievement, i'll post the link once I am finished rendering and uploading that series.My two only complaints: Quest list & Vitality Restoration ProcessQuest list: There is none, you either have to remember what you have to do, or do one task at a time.Vitality Restoration: Takes a long time with no way of skipping the, "scene," you'll hear me say skip to the next video with ~10minutes left because all I was doing was restoring my vitality.(no vit bar btw, so people can abuse that just fyi if a dev comes along and reads this)

Posted: July 29, 2014
												Nice little game. Got it on sale and finished it within about 4 hours with all achievements in two sittings (and then I only stopped for food). It’s a nice, casual point and click type of adventure, with elements of hidden objects. Your task is to save the Kingdom by completing various quests, with most of these quests requiring you to find or buy certain items. You collect herbs and mushrooms. Fish and hunt and even take part in a few battles. Everything you do is fairly self-explanatory. Don’t expect epic gameplay, but for a casual game to while away a few hours this really does the job. The simplistic and casual style may not be for everyone though. The game is also a bit too short. In summary I’d say it’s a good game to get while on sale.

Posted: November 12, 2015
												This was just a game that I was slightly interested in and I think I got it when it was on sale. Actually had a lot of fun playing it, beat it all in 4 hours. It took a bit to get into the play style but loved it after I did. I really like games where you have a lot of things you can do but don't absolutely have to do them in the same order as everyone else. Wish it was longer. But great game.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												This isn't really an RPG- it's more a point-and-click adventure story/hidden object game. It's short,  linear and there's almost no possibility of failure. Gameplay is simply a matter of "find obstacle, collect the items to pass obstacle, pass obstacle, rinse and repeat". The bulk of the challenge is simply juggling the barter system to obtain the objects you need or working out how to get enough gold to proceed.That said, the game is moderately entertaining as a short-term time-waster and actually tells a surprisingly decent, if shallow, story of how your ordinary farmboy rises up to become the savior of the land. It's not original by any means, but it's very back-to-basics. If you're a completionist or achievement hound then there are a fair few challenges to kill time, but I beat it with 100% completion in about 4 hours at most (quite a lot of which was spent searching for those DAMNED last few eggs). I can't in good faith call it a "good game" but I don't have the heart to give it a downvote- even if plot and gameplay were both very shallow, it was cheap and it entertained me for a while and it had a peculiar charm to it. So as long as you don't expect too much, I guess I can give it a casual recommendation.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												This is a very casual rpg game using point and click interactions. There are some side quests in the game, and a simple plotline that's easy to follow. I honestly didn't expect much when I started playing, but the game was surprisingly easy to immerse yourself into. The game itself calls for some degree of knowing how to utilize your current resources, and planning out how to gain future resources. And the constant to and fro barter system, along with seeking out resources along the map, might seem a tad tedious to some people. But, all in all, I would say that this is the game for someone looking for some relaxing and fun gaming.

												This game was suprisingly good. Posted: August 3, 2015
												Steam really needs a "neutral" rec setting, dang. Okay so... this is as generic as fantasy-setting games get, story-wise, and it is painfully simple gameplay that ultimately you can't fail; you can screw up specific actions (hunting, crafting) and break gear but you have more than enough resources at your disposal to make up for that. The biggest difficulty comes in trying to track down the last few random gathering items to finish out all your achievements before you go defeat the Dark Lord (yes). There's a discussion thread where people have shared locations of some of the tricky-to-find items, though, which helped me.Buy this game if it's on sale (I paid $1.25), you have nothing to do for an afternoon, and you get enough satisfaction out of 100% completion that you don't need compelling story or gameplay to back that up.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												I've really enjoyed this game. I beat it from start to finish in about 6 hours of actual playtime, so it's quite short. The game flows very well and the story is nice. It has a very strange way of pulling you in. For the first 30 minutes of the game I felt like I was going to be bored and was wondering if I'd continue playing it, and also felt that it was a bit simple and small... And then I quickly realized how mistaken I was when the world opened up. My mind went from thinking that everything was small scale and simple to, "Oh my god this is going to take me forever to explore all of this."There's quite a lot of easy achievements in the game if you're an achievement hunter. Overall this game is well worth the price. It doesn't really have any replay value, but it's worth the money especially if you get it in a bundle or when it's on sale. I'm very eager to play the 2nd as I enjoyed this one very much and will be looking for future work from this developer.This game does a good job of giving you instant gratification and making you want to play from start to finish in one go. It might take some a bit longer, especially if they're trying to go for all of the achievements or if they're trying to reveal the story to all of the side quests instead of just trying to complete the main story. I wouldn't imagine it has any more than 10 hours of total solid gameplay though, but still well worth full price in my opinion. I have nothing negative to say about this game, it's just so well constructed in a very surprisingly simple weird way. I loved it.10/10 will be buying the sequal and will be looking for future games from this developer.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												Played all the game thru. Simple from the first look but it captured me and I finished it in one breath. Recommended for fans of RPGs who have no much time.

Posted: July 8, 2015
												I'm really not sure about reviews that call this a 'clicker' game of the Clicker Heroes/Adventure Capitalist ilk. This is nothing like those. Yes, fundamentally, you just click. But that's true of Monkey Island and Minesweeper, and no one would call those clickers.Now that I've got that off of my chest, time for the real review. This game borrows heavily from 90's D&D-based CRPGs. It's got the same visual style, and the same sort of subquests, gathering, improving skills and back-and-forth. But it doesn't have any of the D&D elements of those games. You're not roleplaying, managing your inventory or obsessing over stats. It's a simple, quick, fun waste of time. And sometimes, those are just what you want.I wouldn't pay full price for it, but see it on sale or in a bundle? Snap it up.

Posted: August 4, 2015
												I had fun playing this game. That's all about I can say. You just point and click the entire game. Do errands for people to advance and get more and more items. That's it. It's follows a simple and "cliched" story, like the old rpg games. I liked, and people shouldn't expect more. The art reminds me of the classic old games, and for a 2D style it's pretty good, with lots of details (especially if you're willing to find all the items, like I did, to get 100% on the achievements). Posted: August 3, 2015
												Steam really needs a "neutral" rec setting, dang. Okay so... this is as generic as fantasy-setting games get, story-wise, and it is painfully simple gameplay that ultimately you can't fail; you can screw up specific actions (hunting, crafting) and break gear but you have more than enough resources at your disposal to make up for that. The biggest difficulty comes in trying to track down the last few random gathering items to finish out all your achievements before you go defeat the Dark Lord (yes). There's a discussion thread where people have shared locations of some of the tricky-to-find items, though, which helped me.Buy this game if it's on sale (I paid $1.25), you have nothing to do for an afternoon, and you get enough satisfaction out of 100% completion that you don't need compelling story or gameplay to back that up.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												Not quite sure how to categorize Hero of the Kingdom. It's part point-and-click adventure, part interactive story (but effectively linear), part resource management, part "hidden items," part collection quest, _none_ of those genres i particularly care for. Nonetheless, i thoroughly enjoyed the casual, at-your-own-pace nature of this game, as well as the music, the interface (trivial to use), and theme. It's short - i played through it in a single sitting of (Steam says) just under 6  hours (didn't bother to go for 100% of achievements). Combat is unique in that in order to fight, you have to collect certain resources (one of which is fatigue (which is collected by resting)), at which point success is guaranteed. Will i play it again? i might. In terms of cost-per-hour it's already paid for itself, though, and there's nothing left to do in the game except go for the 100% achievements (but i'm not quite that OCD). The next day i went searching for more and promptly found Hero of the Kingdom 2, so it seems that my Saturday is now booked.

												I find this game relaxing yet adictive.you can't go wrong for the price of french fries.Try the demo, if you like it, <$2 is well worth it, unless you are looking for fast paced combat!Basically it is a resorce management game within a common, good vs evil story.It may seem as if you can go where you want, when you want, but eventually, you are guided from A to B to C etc.There is a bit of hidden object to it where you try to find very minute things hidden in the landscape, which can give you a lot of inventory. speaking of which, the hardest part is remembering who buys and sell what. although getting around is easy, your quests require certain items to accomplish (including rest). vendors and quest points are well labeled, but where did they sell that tool I just broke? you are never seen nor have to walk across the screen, just click on the place with an icon and you are there, or the map system will instantly transport you across the world.the trick is keeping your funds up by using tools to aquire items that are hopefully worth more than the tools, and knowing where to use or sell them. 'So, try then buy it, (on sale) you can't help but become the hero.

Posted: May 15, 2016
												Excellent little game! At first I was worried because of the way it took me by the hand during the first 5 minutes or so. But my worries dissipated after the game and quests opened up wide to allow some interesting decision-making. It was just the right level of challenge to complete all of the achievements. The story, although not very original or believable, is imersive and entertaining. I see people complaining about 2 things and I'd like to adress them. 1 - "It's like a facebook game". People say that because of the energy system and kind of exploration + completing quests gameplay. Yes, the gameplay is really an interactive story with exploration, hidden objects, collection and trading, so be aware. On the other hand, it does not have those annoying time limits, inviting friends and premium currency. You don't even have to wait for your energy to be low to recharge it - there's no limit to how much energy you can carry so although it's not realistic, you can rest repeatedly and build up lots of energy to then do your actions. Also, this game has an END. It does not have seasonal events and added content. So I see a monstruous gap between this game and a facebook one, I love this game and hate the ones on facebook. Huge difference.2 - "The game is too short". For the people who say that, I recommend a youtube video called "in defense of short games", from the channel Extra Credits. They explain it a lot better than I could write here. But basically if people keep on judging games only by the lenght of the gameplay, we will get longer games that provides us a poorer experience. Everybody knows at least one TV series of movie franchise that got streched to the point it became so bad it was not worth watching. We need to end this way of thinking. The lenght was perfectly fine for me. I finished the game in 2 sittings of about 3 hous each, reading every dialogue line and getting all achievements before ending the game. Isn't that enough gameplay? There are too many other games out there I'd like to experience before getting stuck with a single game that provides "endless gameplay" or something.If I had to complain about one thing in the game, would be the pace of the action resolution sequences. Everytime an item drops, I need to collect it before moving on. Everytime I choose to perform an action, I need to wait until it is done to do something else. I'd like to be able to do several actions at once, clicking the next one before the previous one is completed, then collect their rewards. Or at least click several actions and "queue" them. It would make the game more dynamic. Also, the nighttime sequence is too long for something that will be repeated several times during the game.9/10

Posted: March 7, 2016
http://intronerdedliving.blogspot.ca/2016/03/hero-of-kingdom-game-review-1010.htmlHero of the Kingdom - Game Review - 10/10     Hero of the Kingdom is a casual point and click indie game for $7 on Steam. For a dollar value hour value, it lasted a little over seven hours which is right where I think a game should be priced. I don't play a lot of point and click games, so I took a chance on this one and was pleasantly surprised.     This is one of my favourite types of art-styles to look at, so I thought this game was absolutely beautiful the whole way through. The music was enjoyable to listen to all throughout. The gameplay was simple and crisp. You get energy by resting, then use that energy as a resource to complete other tasks.     One of my favourite parts of this game was as it introduced new things to you through tasks, you would be able to go back through previous areas and find things such as mushrooms or boxes hidden in the scenes. It was really quite fun to look through everything and complete the achievements, read the story, and play through this sweet little game.     To anybody who enjoys a nice casual game, or a rest from their competitive games for a while, I definitely recommend this game. As usual, if you can get this on sale, it's even more worth the price.     For me, this point and click game is a 10/10.~ Kyle

Posted: May 17, 2016
												This isn't really a game in the strictest sense; there is little challenge and there's not a thing in the game that can't be accomplished through simple planning. Yet it is a great story and I had a good time running through it. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who would rather play more action oriented games or those that focus on player agency. This game isn't about action; it is about following along with it's story. If you can get through the make-work there is a really enjoyable experience to be had here. I'd say that it falls somewhere between an interactive novel and a minimalist "walking simulator" style of game with some hidden object and image hunting thrown in.Not for everyone, but a pretty good time for the right kind of player. Well worth the 5.99 price tag.

Posted: July 29, 2014
												Nice little game. Got it on sale and finished it within about 4 hours with all achievements in two sittings (and then I only stopped for food). It’s a nice, casual point and click type of adventure, with elements of hidden objects. Your task is to save the Kingdom by completing various quests, with most of these quests requiring you to find or buy certain items. You collect herbs and mushrooms. Fish and hunt and even take part in a few battles. Everything you do is fairly self-explanatory. Don’t expect epic gameplay, but for a casual game to while away a few hours this really does the job. The simplistic and casual style may not be for everyone though. The game is also a bit too short. In summary I’d say it’s a good game to get while on sale.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												Hero of the Kingdom is like reading a book, you are guided through a story and the participation in the story line is limited to the quest. You can solve them through gathering the items needed to meet the conditions required to solve the quest. The art is beautifull and the detail is amazing, which comes in handy because you have to find very small objects sometimes. The fights are resolves in the same manner as the quests, meeting the required criteria will get you through. The game takes about 7 to 8 hours if you want to get all the achievements. A way to look up unsolved quests would be handy, but even without it, the game is perfectly playable. I enjoyed playing the game and am looking forward to the second game.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												For a point-n-click adventure this is a decent game. The story is slightly interesting, the graphics aren't too shabby. If you are looking for an excuse to click your mouse button for 3.5 ~ 6 hours this is the game for you! I say 3.5 ~ 6 hrs b/c it took me 3.5 to complete the game, and I did it in one sitting, but I didn't bother with trying to get every single achievement, which would probably have added a few hours of "gameplay." There are no puzzles or anything of the like, but you can hunt an fish an forage to your delight. There is a nifty hint button that will help you out if you skip some dialogue or can't remember where you're supposed to go, but it only applies to the main story-line. Doesn't help much with side quests. Not much replayability unless you HAVE to get every last achievement (and don't strive to get them in one play thru.) I'd give it a 5/10, not the best point and click game I've ever played, but definitly not the worst.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												This casual point-and-click game is difficult for me to recommend mostly in part due to the extensive annoyance of every task you perform being a fetch quest. The fact it is extremely linear with very few options in terms of how you complete a quest only exacerbates matters. Either you harvest certain supplies you need, or outright buy them. I expect a certain simplicity with casual games like this, but this seemed to be a bit much in that regard. The story is very minimalistic with writing on par with a young children's story--just enough to make a point. It has very pleasing visuals and sound and the game length felt just about right from a completionist viewpoint.That said, this is a game that would be delightful to play with children. The simple story, hidden-object elements, and resource management just feel like it targets more of a family video-game night and I am reminded of old adventure classics like Mixed Up Mother Goose I would play with my parents and friends when I was young.Other players looking for a light, relaxing gaming experience can just sit down and enjoy the story without any pressures or puzzling to do however, players wanting a game that provides a more thoughtful experience may end up disappointed.

Posted: May 25, 2015
												One of the calmest, most relaxing games I've ever played. After playing for what felt like 10 minutes, an hour and a half had passed. It's not your typical point-and-click, it's more like a FarmVille-style resource management game. However it removes all the stress and uncertainty associated with in-app purchases, as there aren't any! The story and graphics follow like an Age of Empires 2 spin-off, and that's no bad thing. There are also elements of 'Where's Wally' where you try and find things amongst the beautifully rendered landscape, and the game never tries to trip you up or be unfair. The constant rewards give you a real sense of accomplishment as you play. I'm two hours in and I don't expect there to be much more on offer, but I'm more than satisfied with what the game is trying to do. Loved it :)

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Short, simple, and fun enough while it lasts.  This is a very casual and relaxing game, albeit a repetitive one.  I got it for less than two dollars on sale, and to be honest, I wouldn't pay more than that.  There are a couple mechanics the game never properly explains to you, such as finding eggs, mushrooms, crates, and the like.  (You have to click on the tiny little pictures you see on the map; they don't have icons like almost everything else.)  On top of that, a game this simple could have benefited from a marginally more unique story.  I'm not saying you have to construct an epic tale, or anything, but man, you could have attempted SOME sort of a unique plot twist.  I mean, I guess there was one, kind of, but it was the sort of thing you've probably seen a million times before.One of my biggest problems in this game was how hard it is to make money.  One of the hints I was given at some point consisted of doing tasks for people, which would have been all well and good, if it weren't for the fact that pretty much every single task required some sort of payment up front.  Occasionally, you'll get a somewhat sizable-seeming sum, but since everything is so expensive, it'll probably be gone very quickly.  Eventually, I ended up trying to gather and sell all the herbs and fish I could, but none of that stuff ever respawns, as it turns out; once you gather all the herbs and fish at all the fishing spots, it's gone forever.  So if you need that stuff later, as I did, you'll be buying them from the store.When I say I recommend this game, bear in mind that I only recommend it if you can get it for two bucks or less.  This is one of those "I have less than five bucks left in my Steam wallet, what do I do with it?" sort of game, not the kind of thing you should go out of your way to buy.

												I'd originally kind of dismissed this game due to the Casual tag and the simplicity of it, but I liked it once I gave it a try. For anyone on the fence about it, just give the demo a try. My only complaints were: 1. The handholding going on in the beginning and a lack of freedom that went with that. 2. Once you open things up it's hard to keep track of what all you're doing. There's no journal or anything like that. 3. The hint option is what is offered to make up for that. You're essentially offered a Cheat at Any Time button and it's the only way of reminding yourself, for instance, where to go on the map to find the one merchant you need for an objectiveIt's a simple game and lacks features found in bigger offerings, but that does not take away from it being good at what it does have. So, again, try the demo to see if it's something you'd be into or not.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game surprised me. It was extremely relaxing. This is one of those games where you can lay in bed and play with just the mouse. Sure it's a point and click story bookish game, but combined with the cute but immersive graphics, sound effects, music, and dialogue, it successfully pulls the player into its world. Sure the plot was quite predictable but it was quite satisfying as a result. The art was beautifully done, emulating more classical 8-16 bit graphics. I beat the game in two days, however on the second day I couldn't wait to finish school to rush home and continue the story, I just couldn't put this title down until it was finished. It also had quite a unique battle system, if you can call it that... For what this game is, 9/10 from me.Cons:-No replay-ability.-The end game was a tiny bit monotonous but it's a small inconvenience.-Easter egg hunting tiny objects for side-quests is annoying.-Lots of back tracking... and memorization...

												It is a cute, short and simplistic game in which all you do is click around the screen to further the story.The game is akin to a hidden object game, however it is less focused on that and more focused on completing quests which are always completed by simply having the required item on hand, and you can always buy or easily find those items around.You can not lose in this game, you could possibly get stuck in it if you really wanted to by wasting all of your money on things you don't need, but realistically all you need to complete this game is enough patience for a few hours of clicking around the screen and that's it, you will finish it in 2 hours and a half and you will complete most of the quests doing so. Posted: October 20, 2015
												This game is awesome, and not just because it was made by my counrtymen :)It's not exactly an RPG, it's more like a point-and-click adventure with RPG elements and HOG elements. There's a "farmboy has to leave home, ends up saving the world" story, you go out and explore the locations, discovering resources and actions. Each golden icon on the map is an action (like fishing), which needs some resources: tools (fishing rod), consumables (bait) and stamina. You talk to people, help them, learn new skills, all the while searching for your father, who's been taken by bandits.Three hours of casual fun to reset your brain after an honest day's work. Go for it, you'll come back for a replay.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												This casual point-and-click game is difficult for me to recommend mostly in part due to the extensive annoyance of every task you perform being a fetch quest. The fact it is extremely linear with very few options in terms of how you complete a quest only exacerbates matters. Either you harvest certain supplies you need, or outright buy them. I expect a certain simplicity with casual games like this, but this seemed to be a bit much in that regard. The story is very minimalistic with writing on par with a young children's story--just enough to make a point. It has very pleasing visuals and sound and the game length felt just about right from a completionist viewpoint.That said, this is a game that would be delightful to play with children. The simple story, hidden-object elements, and resource management just feel like it targets more of a family video-game night and I am reminded of old adventure classics like Mixed Up Mother Goose I would play with my parents and friends when I was young.Other players looking for a light, relaxing gaming experience can just sit down and enjoy the story without any pressures or puzzling to do however, players wanting a game that provides a more thoughtful experience may end up disappointed.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												Small and nice game if point and click games is your thing.The mood is nice, and the gameplay is kind of catchy because you want to optimize your gathering of resources. And that's basically what you do: Gather resources. You go picking some mushrooms, hunting some animals, getting stuff for people, trading and so on. There's really not much you can do wrong so the gameplay is much about how to optimize your resources. Even combat is a question about having the right resources (e.g. 2 bowmen and 4 healing potions). So if you have the resources you can fight (and win) and if you haven't got the resources you can't attack until you've got them. It's pretty simple and that's actually some of the appeal of this game.I'm not a power player but I like to hunt for achievements.It took me 3,5 hours to complete the game with all the achievements. So it's not a big game. But it was definitely enjoyable.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												Saving the kingdom has never been so... relaxing.Hero of the Kingdom is a very straightforward point-and-click/hidden object game that is cheerfully content with what it is. Each task is simply given a set of resources necessary to complete it, and if you have those resources, you can clear the task. After all, of course the hero of the story makes it through, why pretend otherwise? The hidden objects on each map can usually be converted directly into money, or used to clear various unlock tasks, which are used to gain access to various resources you need.You do end up feeling less than of a hero, and more of a military quartermaster, sourcing local materials and labor to win the campaign against the Dark Lord. But this is what makes the game so relaxing. No timing, no complicated clicking, just knowing where to get the parts you need to assemble your victory. It rewards remembering who sells what, and being able to find eggs in a forest map, rather than actions per second. Even the achievements are hardly difficult (though I really had to search for that last bird's nest).Everything about the game is very polished, as well. The soundtrack fits, the maps progress cleanly from one to the other, and you can always get the resources you need if you're willing to go kill and skin a few wild animals. Even if you sell something you need later in the game to get the money for an immediate goal, there's always someone who will sell it right back to you, usually for the same price you got in the first place.This is a good game to spend a few hours relaxing with.

Posted: November 15, 2016
												So this was a quirky little game I've had my eyes on for a while. Having picked it up on offer, I decided to give it a run-through, and it was a generally pleasant experience. Nothing that stands out in particular in terms of what would set it apart from other games, but nothing that felt like it hampered my experiences either. If you have a few hours to spare and a bit of change, this is worth at least one playthrough to pass the time away. It doesn't have much of worth to bring you back for a second playthrough, but given a reasonable price point and it's worth the one time.The game is essentially a resource management simulation where you have to manage what you have, your energy, money and your skills to eventually become the "Hero of the Kingdom", and honestly, it's not too challenging provided that methodical progression is applied to everything, from levelling your capabilities to ensuring you have enough food or money for the next event you have to overcome. It does have some strategical layer of depth to it (case in point, you can simply buy certain things you need, but if you work on your skills you can get items for much cheaper than you would buying them) and I appreciated the layers that had been taken to reward those who did go a little extra in managing their resources more efficientlyA lot of the gameplay elements are easily visible event points, though one of the other draws of the game is an element of hidden object games, where you find items such as mushrooms or crates for extra items and money. Beyond these elements, it tends to play forward in a more point-and-click adventure game than your typical RPG (a great number of RPG elements are not present here, so if you are looking for an RPG experience, I would advise seeking this elsewhere) and the story it does tell through the story is a simple one, with a neat bow finish after the ending progresses. If any complaint could be thought of, it would be that there's no real sense of time passing by as any of these events transpire - and given that you can rest in camps without any effect to the story does not help in this regard.In terms of the art assets, the landscapes, the various icons and the people you get to see are pleasant to look at, with nothing looking out of the ordinary for a fantasy adventure. The game has a good sound quality to it, from the effects to the music, though it can sometimes be distracting when the track suddenly changes while you've been on a screen for a while without any change. All-in-all, though, the complaints that I have are minor and nit-picky, and did not detract from the fact that I did get enjoyment from the game overall, and while I clocked only about 4-5 hours and obtained all achievements (with others completing it in less time), it was a worthwhile 4-5 hours that I had spent without any regrets.In summary: While a short point-and-click adventure experience, it's hidden object and resource management elements helped keep the gameplay varied and entertaining, while the story and progression was balanced enough that it did not feel like it carried on for too long or too short a time, and it didn't leave any loose ends. It's lack of difficulty or replay value is an appeal for anyone seeking something to plug into for a few hours of their time, and the price value makes this at least worth a purchase on a sale, if not at full price.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												For me, as well as many other reviewers (so it seems) this game was a nice unexpected pleasent surprise.I actually went into game expecting a completely different genre - I thaught it would be a casual town building/management game, what it actually was is nice blend of P&C adventure with nice gamey RPG elements and statistics, and some hidden object elements.While playing it on a small(ish) laptop screen (1366x768) the graphics were nice crisp 2D painting-like pictures reminescent of those detailed, colorful and clear-lined screens of games like Desperados, Commandos, Settlers and in modern times Anno series. This one though is fully in 2d, which I personally like a lot, cause it still manages to deliver more slick, more detailed and thin-lined drawings, opposed to 3d muddying of features caused by texture requirements and antialiasing. I'd argue that 3d engines still aren't capable of producing such fine lines as simple and clear as 2d drawing/sprite and this game uses that fact to the full effect. The visual presentation is, again, clear, colorful and full of small details. So far I'd played for some 2 or 3 hours (ignore the Steam stats, I don't understand why it didn't record the last session) in one sitting and the experience was delightful, the flow of quests and tasks slick and satisfying and gameplay varied enough to still feel interesting, though in the beginning you solely click on few points on screen and manage few basic stats like food and building materials. Slowly you get involved with you character, though his actions aren't described in much verbouse prose, but later when he manageas to learn few skills and has some successful quests uder his belt you do start to care and do notice when he starts calling some officer HIS captain, since he recently enlisted in land's military. The progres from a naive farmboy to adventurer to ultimate hero is a familiar tale, but it's nicely done and somewhat beliveably depicted - in slow careful stages. In this case journey is more satisfying than the end and slow exploring of map, solving quests and "leveling up" (though the only stat connected to that is reputation) makes a nice calm romp. So my overal oppinion is that it's competent and surprizingly fun casual P&C adventure. It has earned my recommendation fair and square, the same way as the annonymous hero will earn to be the Hero of his Kingdom.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Short, simple, and fun enough while it lasts.  This is a very casual and relaxing game, albeit a repetitive one.  I got it for less than two dollars on sale, and to be honest, I wouldn't pay more than that.  There are a couple mechanics the game never properly explains to you, such as finding eggs, mushrooms, crates, and the like.  (You have to click on the tiny little pictures you see on the map; they don't have icons like almost everything else.)  On top of that, a game this simple could have benefited from a marginally more unique story.  I'm not saying you have to construct an epic tale, or anything, but man, you could have attempted SOME sort of a unique plot twist.  I mean, I guess there was one, kind of, but it was the sort of thing you've probably seen a million times before.One of my biggest problems in this game was how hard it is to make money.  One of the hints I was given at some point consisted of doing tasks for people, which would have been all well and good, if it weren't for the fact that pretty much every single task required some sort of payment up front.  Occasionally, you'll get a somewhat sizable-seeming sum, but since everything is so expensive, it'll probably be gone very quickly.  Eventually, I ended up trying to gather and sell all the herbs and fish I could, but none of that stuff ever respawns, as it turns out; once you gather all the herbs and fish at all the fishing spots, it's gone forever.  So if you need that stuff later, as I did, you'll be buying them from the store.When I say I recommend this game, bear in mind that I only recommend it if you can get it for two bucks or less.  This is one of those "I have less than five bucks left in my Steam wallet, what do I do with it?" sort of game, not the kind of thing you should go out of your way to buy.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												Small and nice game if point and click games is your thing.The mood is nice, and the gameplay is kind of catchy because you want to optimize your gathering of resources. And that's basically what you do: Gather resources. You go picking some mushrooms, hunting some animals, getting stuff for people, trading and so on. There's really not much you can do wrong so the gameplay is much about how to optimize your resources. Even combat is a question about having the right resources (e.g. 2 bowmen and 4 healing potions). So if you have the resources you can fight (and win) and if you haven't got the resources you can't attack until you've got them. It's pretty simple and that's actually some of the appeal of this game.I'm not a power player but I like to hunt for achievements.It took me 3,5 hours to complete the game with all the achievements. So it's not a big game. But it was definitely enjoyable.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												Saving the kingdom has never been so... relaxing.Hero of the Kingdom is a very straightforward point-and-click/hidden object game that is cheerfully content with what it is. Each task is simply given a set of resources necessary to complete it, and if you have those resources, you can clear the task. After all, of course the hero of the story makes it through, why pretend otherwise? The hidden objects on each map can usually be converted directly into money, or used to clear various unlock tasks, which are used to gain access to various resources you need.You do end up feeling less than of a hero, and more of a military quartermaster, sourcing local materials and labor to win the campaign against the Dark Lord. But this is what makes the game so relaxing. No timing, no complicated clicking, just knowing where to get the parts you need to assemble your victory. It rewards remembering who sells what, and being able to find eggs in a forest map, rather than actions per second. Even the achievements are hardly difficult (though I really had to search for that last bird's nest).Everything about the game is very polished, as well. The soundtrack fits, the maps progress cleanly from one to the other, and you can always get the resources you need if you're willing to go kill and skin a few wild animals. Even if you sell something you need later in the game to get the money for an immediate goal, there's always someone who will sell it right back to you, usually for the same price you got in the first place.This is a good game to spend a few hours relaxing with.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												This game surprised me. It was extremely relaxing. This is one of those games where you can lay in bed and play with just the mouse. Sure it's a point and click story bookish game, but combined with the cute but immersive graphics, sound effects, music, and dialogue, it successfully pulls the player into its world. Sure the plot was quite predictable but it was quite satisfying as a result. The art was beautifully done, emulating more classical 8-16 bit graphics. I beat the game in two days, however on the second day I couldn't wait to finish school to rush home and continue the story, I just couldn't put this title down until it was finished. It also had quite a unique battle system, if you can call it that... For what this game is, 9/10 from me.Cons:-No replay-ability.-The end game was a tiny bit monotonous but it's a small inconvenience.-Easter egg hunting tiny objects for side-quests is annoying.-Lots of back tracking... and memorization...

That in itself is not so much a problem because it's still fun, but it doesn't offer any replay value in terms of experiencing a different adventure the 2nd time through.Basically, it's a point & click adventure in the literal sense that you will have to click.. a lot. The game is set up in a way that you could never fail it unless maybe you were deliberately trying to - and even then I question the possibility. For that matter it can be said that the game is somewhat of the easy nature. Really, the only real challenge in this game is getting 100% of the achievements / completion. The story is pretty straightforward and not really memorable but there are a lot of hidden 'secrets' and things to look out for which makes this a great game for those who are into exploration or putting their eyes and mind to the test.

Posted: May 15, 2016
												Excellent little game! At first I was worried because of the way it took me by the hand during the first 5 minutes or so. But my worries dissipated after the game and quests opened up wide to allow some interesting decision-making. It was just the right level of challenge to complete all of the achievements. The story, although not very original or believable, is imersive and entertaining. I see people complaining about 2 things and I'd like to adress them. 1 - "It's like a facebook game". People say that because of the energy system and kind of exploration + completing quests gameplay. Yes, the gameplay is really an interactive story with exploration, hidden objects, collection and trading, so be aware. On the other hand, it does not have those annoying time limits, inviting friends and premium currency. You don't even have to wait for your energy to be low to recharge it - there's no limit to how much energy you can carry so although it's not realistic, you can rest repeatedly and build up lots of energy to then do your actions. Also, this game has an END. It does not have seasonal events and added content. So I see a monstruous gap between this game and a facebook one, I love this game and hate the ones on facebook. Huge difference.2 - "The game is too short". For the people who say that, I recommend a youtube video called "in defense of short games", from the channel Extra Credits. They explain it a lot better than I could write here. But basically if people keep on judging games only by the lenght of the gameplay, we will get longer games that provides us a poorer experience. Everybody knows at least one TV series of movie franchise that got streched to the point it became so bad it was not worth watching. We need to end this way of thinking. The lenght was perfectly fine for me. I finished the game in 2 sittings of about 3 hous each, reading every dialogue line and getting all achievements before ending the game. Isn't that enough gameplay? There are too many other games out there I'd like to experience before getting stuck with a single game that provides "endless gameplay" or something.If I had to complain about one thing in the game, would be the pace of the action resolution sequences. Everytime an item drops, I need to collect it before moving on. Everytime I choose to perform an action, I need to wait until it is done to do something else. I'd like to be able to do several actions at once, clicking the next one before the previous one is completed, then collect their rewards. Or at least click several actions and "queue" them. It would make the game more dynamic. Also, the nighttime sequence is too long for something that will be repeated several times during the game.9/10

Posted: March 7, 2016
http://intronerdedliving.blogspot.ca/2016/03/hero-of-kingdom-game-review-1010.htmlHero of the Kingdom - Game Review - 10/10     Hero of the Kingdom is a casual point and click indie game for $7 on Steam. For a dollar value hour value, it lasted a little over seven hours which is right where I think a game should be priced. I don't play a lot of point and click games, so I took a chance on this one and was pleasantly surprised.     This is one of my favourite types of art-styles to look at, so I thought this game was absolutely beautiful the whole way through. The music was enjoyable to listen to all throughout. The gameplay was simple and crisp. You get energy by resting, then use that energy as a resource to complete other tasks.     One of my favourite parts of this game was as it introduced new things to you through tasks, you would be able to go back through previous areas and find things such as mushrooms or boxes hidden in the scenes. It was really quite fun to look through everything and complete the achievements, read the story, and play through this sweet little game.     To anybody who enjoys a nice casual game, or a rest from their competitive games for a while, I definitely recommend this game. As usual, if you can get this on sale, it's even more worth the price.     For me, this point and click game is a 10/10.~ Kyle

Posted: May 11, 2016
												While this game is no RPG at all, it is worth the buy on sale. Full price is not really a fair buy, as the game is really short (I got all the achievements) and has no replay value at all. It is essentially a casual clicker game with some hidden object dimension in it (more below). You go on from map to map, gathering food, objects, speaking to uninteresting NPCs, and accomplishing some dull quests for them. Yet, the game is catchy, and you can finish it in a row as it keeps being entertaining. You cannot die nor make mistakes, it is pretty easy, but it's fun. To make some more money (necessary for quests) you can grab some objects hidden on the maps, such as mushrooms, fishes, crevices, eggs, and you can hunt animals. Strangely enough, becoming the Hero of the Kingdom also means plundering it from all its natural resources. This hidden dimension is nice as the objects have not been put randomly: eggs can be found in the forest or on cliffs, mushrooms are found near the woods. Everything makes sense. The story has no interest at all. They could hardly have done a less interesting one. Too bad as it would have make the game better.Finally, the late game is tedious. You have to fish everything and hunt every animals, so you need energy and you spend most of your time sleeping. Repetitive fights (where a fight means gathering enough potions trhgouh trade and then automatically resolve it for a guaranteed win) are just utterly boring. Without the pleasure of discovering new areas as all the bad guys are found in already visited places, it looses all interest. Conclusion: A good game to buy on sale and spent a relaxing and entertaining yet too short time.

Posted: November 15, 2016
												So this was a quirky little game I've had my eyes on for a while. Having picked it up on offer, I decided to give it a run-through, and it was a generally pleasant experience. Nothing that stands out in particular in terms of what would set it apart from other games, but nothing that felt like it hampered my experiences either. If you have a few hours to spare and a bit of change, this is worth at least one playthrough to pass the time away. It doesn't have much of worth to bring you back for a second playthrough, but given a reasonable price point and it's worth the one time.The game is essentially a resource management simulation where you have to manage what you have, your energy, money and your skills to eventually become the "Hero of the Kingdom", and honestly, it's not too challenging provided that methodical progression is applied to everything, from levelling your capabilities to ensuring you have enough food or money for the next event you have to overcome. It does have some strategical layer of depth to it (case in point, you can simply buy certain things you need, but if you work on your skills you can get items for much cheaper than you would buying them) and I appreciated the layers that had been taken to reward those who did go a little extra in managing their resources more efficientlyA lot of the gameplay elements are easily visible event points, though one of the other draws of the game is an element of hidden object games, where you find items such as mushrooms or crates for extra items and money. Beyond these elements, it tends to play forward in a more point-and-click adventure game than your typical RPG (a great number of RPG elements are not present here, so if you are looking for an RPG experience, I would advise seeking this elsewhere) and the story it does tell through the story is a simple one, with a neat bow finish after the ending progresses. If any complaint could be thought of, it would be that there's no real sense of time passing by as any of these events transpire - and given that you can rest in camps without any effect to the story does not help in this regard.In terms of the art assets, the landscapes, the various icons and the people you get to see are pleasant to look at, with nothing looking out of the ordinary for a fantasy adventure. The game has a good sound quality to it, from the effects to the music, though it can sometimes be distracting when the track suddenly changes while you've been on a screen for a while without any change. All-in-all, though, the complaints that I have are minor and nit-picky, and did not detract from the fact that I did get enjoyment from the game overall, and while I clocked only about 4-5 hours and obtained all achievements (with others completing it in less time), it was a worthwhile 4-5 hours that I had spent without any regrets.In summary: While a short point-and-click adventure experience, it's hidden object and resource management elements helped keep the gameplay varied and entertaining, while the story and progression was balanced enough that it did not feel like it carried on for too long or too short a time, and it didn't leave any loose ends. It's lack of difficulty or replay value is an appeal for anyone seeking something to plug into for a few hours of their time, and the price value makes this at least worth a purchase on a sale, if not at full price.

Hero of the KingdomSynopsis:You were living a calm life on your farm with your father. Those times are gone. Flames have turned your house into ashes. Your father is missing. A darkness is falling over the whole country and you are setting off on a dangerous journey. This is going to be the greatest adventure of your life.Pros:- Lot hunting map for items and materials.- Side quest, intriguing- Several places to explore.Cons:- History a little cliché- Short GameScores:History - 4/10Music - 6/10Graphics - 5/10Contents - 7/10Gameplay - 8/10Final Opinion:I've never been much of a fan of click point games, but this actually caught me in such a way that when I found out I was already exploring everything in the game offered. For those who never play this kind genre will not regret playing this.So I do recommend it.Note: 7/10

Posted: January 11
												This game is so simple but awesome enough to play twice! It doesn't take a nice PC/Mac to play this because it's simply clicking (but it feels like you're doing more). Here are the things I love about this game:It's sort of like an I Spy game in which you're trying to find resources in various landscapes - so that feels like a mini game in and of itself. And as you progress, you have to go back and look at old maps/landscapes to see what suddenly appears now that you have the skill to gather/hunt it, etc.There are a few crafting/assembly lines you can use to make money. Many you must use to progress in the game because you need a various item. For example, you end up needing bread quite often to heal/sleep and to help others. You can buy the grain, take it to the mill and pay for it to be ground into flour, then you take it to the bread maker, and then you sell it for a small profit. It takes patience but I love that it does because the reward is all the greater. It has acheivements which are super fun for completionists. I am still trying to get all of them - so close! I can't find a couple of things on any of the maps! But that is fun to me because it means more time playing the game of I Spy.The story progresses perfectly without hitches. There are no glitches and everything you need is basically given to you if you focus on progressing through each map before you complete everything in it. The more maps you have the more opportunities you have to gather/hunt/find the stuff you need for free. It also unlocks more things in the maps you need to go back to anyway. I can tell this game has been thouroughly tested for bugs.It's fun to make money in this game! Due to the assemply-line type of things like bread or potions, you end up doing some simple math to figure out who gives you the best deal on the supplies to gather, and who will buy what you've gathered for the highest price. Also, it's fun to figure out which camp is cheaper to camp in based on what resources you need to camp there. I can easily play this game in windowed mode at work. When I have nothing to do but want to look busy, I just pull it up and play. The simplicity of it makes it easy to be disracted from and come back to just to pick up where you left off. My only complaint is that the story is your typical saving someone you love just to find out that you have to defeat a bad guy to save everyone. That being said though, the story was fun enough.This game has obviously been translated from another language and is hilarious to read sometimes. Everything makes perfect sense but it's said in a way that sounds like a literal translation from one language to another with no account for the differences in grammar/common use of words between the languages. I think anyone who likes the types of things I mentioned above would love this game. My mom doesn't like most games, especially not adventure/RPG games, but I honestly think she would find this fun due to the "puzzles" (where to go to get what to solve various tasks) and the I Spy part of it. Be warned though - if you play windowed you need good glasses or good eyesight because things are tiny and very subtle. To me that makes it more fun though. PS the only reason I have logged over 100 hours on the game is because I've left it open in the background at work. Being anal about all the acheivements has given me about 10 hours of gameplay, versus the 4 others claim to have gotten out of it.

Posted: January 18
												This game is a puzzle/resource management game. It has nice oldschool graphics, with the feeling from the strategy medieval games from the 90s. It tries to simulate an RPG where you follow a story with your character and do a lot of fighting and tasks, but essentially you are just trying to find hidden stuff in the maps, or find your way through the dozens of maps that keep opening up, doing tasks like building, harvesting and helping people out. This is a game to play when you need to relax, because there ain't no thought envolved besides finding you way and what to do next. I don't think it is possible to "fail" in this game, unless you really try to, so everyone will probably finish it in no time. It is a short game.OCD people will have plenty of fun completing tasks, unlocking achievements and progressing, this is what this game is all about. I bought it during a sale and I can recommend it for low prices, otherwise, buy it  if you are a fan of casual games or are desperate for a feel of the 90s, but keep in mind the game is simple and short so most people will prefer to pay pocket change for it.
